The [U.S. Census Bureau](/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau "United States Census Bureau") estimates that the district's population was 705,749 as of July 2019, up more than 100,000 people since the [2010 United States Census](/wiki/2010_United_States_Census "2010 United States Census"). When measured decade-over-decade, this shows growth since 2000, following a half-century of population decline.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-135)^ Washington was the [24th-most populous place](/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population "List of United States cities by population") in the United States as of 2010^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Washington,_D.C.&action=edit)^.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-136)^ According to data from 2010, commuters from the suburbs boost the district's daytime population past one million.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-137)^ If the district were a state, it would rank [49th in population](/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_and_territories_by_population "List of U.S. states and territories by population"), ahead of [Vermont](/wiki/Vermont "Vermont") and [Wyoming](/wiki/Wyoming "Wyoming").^[\[133\]](#cite_note-quickfacts-138)^{#cite_ref-quickfacts_138-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Race_and_ethnicity_2010-_Washington%2C_DC_%285559893527%29.png/220px-Race_and_ethnicity_2010-_Washington%2C_DC_%285559893527%29.png)](/wiki/File:Race_and_ethnicity_2010-_Washington,_DC_(5559893527).png) Map of racial distribution in the [Washington metropolitan area](/wiki/Washington_metropolitan_area "Washington metropolitan area"), according to the [2010 U.S. census](/wiki/2010_United_States_census "2010 United States census"); each dot represents 25 people: **White**, **Black**, **Asian**, **Hispanic** or **Other** (yellow)

The [Washington metropolitan area](/wiki/Washington_metropolitan_area "Washington metropolitan area"), which includes the district and surrounding suburbs, is the [sixth-largest](/wiki/Table_of_United_States_Metropolitan_Statistical_Areas "Table of United States Metropolitan Statistical Areas") metropolitan area in the U.S., with an estimated six million residents as of 2016.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-139)^ When the Washington area is included with [Baltimore](/wiki/Baltimore "Baltimore") and its suburbs, it forms the vast [Washington--Baltimore combined statistical area](/wiki/Washington%E2%80%93Baltimore_combined_statistical_area "Washington–Baltimore combined statistical area"). With a population exceeding 9.8 million residents in 2020, it is the [third-largest](/wiki/List_of_United_States_combined_statistical_areas "List of United States combined statistical areas") combined statistical area in the country.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-140)^{#cite_ref-140}

According to [Department of Housing and Development](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Housing_and_Urban_Development "United States Department of Housing and Urban Development")'s [Annual Homeless Assessment Report](/wiki/Annual_Homeless_Assessment_Report_to_Congress "Annual Homeless Assessment Report to Congress") in 2022, there were an estimated 4,410 [homeless](/wiki/Homelessness "Homelessness") people in Washington, D.C.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-141)^^[\[137\]](#cite_note-142)^{#cite_ref-142}

According to 2020 Census Bureau data, the population of Washington, D.C., was 41.4% Black or African American, 39.6% White (37.9% non-Hispanic White), 4.9% [Asian](/wiki/Asian_American "Asian American"), 0.5% American Indian or Alaska Native, 0.1% Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander, and 5.4% Some Other Race. Individuals from two or more races made up 8.1% of the population. Hispanics of any race made up 11.3% of the district's population.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-Census2020-126)^{#cite_ref-Census2020_126-1}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Leffler_-_1968_Washington%2C_D.C._Martin_Luther_King%2C_Jr._riots.jpg/220px-Leffler_-_1968_Washington%2C_D.C._Martin_Luther_King%2C_Jr._riots.jpg)](/wiki/File:Leffler_-_1968_Washington,_D.C._Martin_Luther_King,_Jr._riots.jpg) The city's African American population has declined since the [1968 riots](/wiki/1968_Washington,_D.C.,_riots "1968 Washington, D.C., riots").

Washington, D.C. has had a relatively large [African American population](/wiki/List_of_U.S._cities_with_large_African-American_populations "List of U.S. cities with large African-American populations") since the city's foundation.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-143)^ African American residents composed about 30% of the district's total population between 1800 and 1940.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-histpop-46)^ The black population reached a peak of 70% by 1970 and has since declined as African Americans moved to the surrounding suburbs. Partly as a result of [gentrification](/wiki/Gentrification "Gentrification"), there was a 31.4% increase in the non-Hispanic white population and an 11.5% decrease in the black population between 2000 and 2010.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-demshift-144)^ According to a study by the National Community Reinvestment Coalition, D.C. has experienced more "intense" gentrification than any other American city, with 40% of neighborhoods gentrified.^[\[140\]](#cite_note-145)^{#cite_ref-145}

As of 2010, about 17% of Washington, D.C. residents were age 18 or younger, which is lower than the U.S. average of 24%. However, at 34 years old, the district had the lowest median age compared to the 50 states as of 2010.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-146)^ As of 2010^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Washington,_D.C.&action=edit)^, there were an estimated 81,734 [immigrants](/wiki/Immigrants "Immigrants") living in Washington, D.C.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-DCsocial-147)^ Major sources of immigration include [El Salvador](/wiki/El_Salvador "El Salvador"), [Ethiopia](/wiki/Ethiopia "Ethiopia"), [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"), [Guatemala](/wiki/Guatemala "Guatemala"), and [China](/wiki/China "China"), with a concentration of Salvadorans in the [Mount Pleasant](/wiki/Mount_Pleasant,_Washington,_D.C. "Mount Pleasant, Washington, D.C.") neighborhood.^[\[143\]](#cite_note-148)^{#cite_ref-148}

As of 2010, there were 4,822 same-sex couples in the city, about 2% of total households, according to [Williams Institute](/wiki/Williams_Institute "Williams Institute").^[\[144\]](#cite_note-149)^ Legislation [authorizing same-sex marriage](/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_the_District_of_Columbia "Same-sex marriage in the District of Columbia") passed in 2009, and the district began issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples in March 2010.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-150)^{#cite_ref-150}  
Notable religious buildings in Washington, D.C.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_the_Immaculate_Conception%2C_Washington.jpg/164px-Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_the_Immaculate_Conception%2C_Washington.jpg)](/wiki/File:Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_the_Immaculate_Conception,_Washington.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Islamic_Center%2C_Washington%2C_D.C_LCCN2011630761.jpg/220px-Islamic_Center%2C_Washington%2C_D.C_LCCN2011630761.jpg)](/wiki/File:Islamic_Center,_Washington,_D.C_LCCN2011630761.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/6th%26ISynagogue.jpg/215px-6th%26ISynagogue.jpg)](/wiki/File:6th%26ISynagogue.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/St._John%27s_Episcopal_Church_Lafayette_Square.jpg/169px-St._John%27s_Episcopal_Church_Lafayette_Square.jpg)](/wiki/File:St._John%27s_Episcopal_Church_Lafayette_Square.jpg)  
Left to right from the top: The [Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception](/wiki/Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_the_Immaculate_Conception "Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception"); the [Islamic Center of Washington](/wiki/Islamic_Center_of_Washington "Islamic Center of Washington"); the [Sixth \& I Historic Synagogue](/wiki/Sixth_%26_I_Historic_Synagogue "Sixth & I Historic Synagogue"); and [St. John's Episcopal Church](/wiki/St._John%27s_Episcopal_Church,_Lafayette_Square "St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square")

As of 2007, about one-third of Washington, D.C., residents were [functionally illiterate](/wiki/Functionally_illiterate "Functionally illiterate"), more than the national rate of about one in five. The city's relatively high illiteracy rate is attributed in part to immigrants who are not proficient in English.^[\[146\]](#cite_note-151)^ As of 2011^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Washington,_D.C.&action=edit)^, 85% of D.C. residents age 5 and older spoke English at home as a primary language.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-152)^ Half of residents had at least a four-year college degree in 2006.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-DCsocial-147)^ In 2017, the median household income in D.C. was $77,649;^[\[148\]](#cite_note-DC_AF-153)^ also in 2017, D.C. residents had a [personal income per capita](/wiki/States_of_the_United_States_of_America_by_income "States of the United States of America by income") of $50,832 (higher than any of the 50 states).^[\[148\]](#cite_note-DC_AF-153)^^[\[149\]](#cite_note-154)^ However, 19% of residents were below the poverty level in 2005, higher than any state except [Mississippi](/wiki/Mississippi "Mississippi"). In 2019, the poverty rate stood at 14.7%.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-155)^^[\[f\]](#cite_note-157)^^[\[152\]](#cite_note-158)^{#cite_ref-158}

As of 2010^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Washington,_D.C.&action=edit)^, more than 90% of Washington, D.C., residents had health insurance coverage, the second-highest rate in the nation. This is due in part to city programs that help provide insurance to low-income individuals who do not qualify for other types of coverage.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-159)^^\[*[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")*\]^ A 2009 report found that at least three percent of Washington, D.C., residents have [HIV](/wiki/HIV "HIV") or [AIDS](/wiki/HIV/AIDS "HIV/AIDS"), which the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention "Centers for Disease Control and Prevention") (CDC) characterizes as a "generalized and severe" epidemic.^[\[154\]](#cite_note-160)^{#cite_ref-160}

As of 2020, according to the [Association of Statisticians of American Religious Bodies](/wiki/Association_of_Statisticians_of_American_Religious_Bodies "Association of Statisticians of American Religious Bodies"), 56% of the city's residents were adherents^[\[g\]](#cite_note-162)^ of a religious body. The largest tradition represented was [Evangelical Protestantism](/wiki/Evangelical_Protestantism "Evangelical Protestantism") (15% of total population), followed by [Catholicism](/wiki/Catholicism "Catholicism") (12%), [Black Protestantism](/wiki/Black_Protestantism "Black Protestantism") (10%), [Mainline Protestantism](/wiki/Mainline_Protestantism "Mainline Protestantism") (10%), [Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism") (3%), [Orthodox Christianity](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodoxy "Eastern Orthodoxy") (2%), [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism") (1%), and [Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam") (1%), with several other groups numbering less than 1%. Mainline Protestants were the largest group in 2010, Catholics in 2000, and Black Protestants in 1990.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-ARDA-161)^ The city is populated with many religious buildings, including the [Washington National Cathedral](/wiki/Washington_National_Cathedral "Washington National Cathedral"), the [Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception](/wiki/Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_the_Immaculate_Conception "Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception"), which comprises the [largest Catholic church building in the United States](/wiki/List_of_largest_church_buildings "List of largest church buildings"), and the [Islamic Center of Washington](/wiki/Islamic_Center_of_Washington "Islamic Center of Washington"), which was the largest [mosque](/wiki/Mosque "Mosque") in the Western Hemisphere when opened in 1957. [St. John's Episcopal Church](/wiki/St._John%27s_Episcopal_Church,_Lafayette_Square "St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square"), located off [Lafayette Square](/wiki/Lafayette_Square_(Washington,_D.C.) "Lafayette Square (Washington, D.C.)"), has held services for every [U.S. president](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States") since [James Madison](/wiki/James_Madison "James Madison"). The [Sixth \& I Historic Synagogue](/wiki/Sixth_%26_I_Historic_Synagogue "Sixth & I Historic Synagogue"), built in 1908, is a [synagogue](/wiki/Synagogue "Synagogue") located in the [Chinatown](/wiki/Chinatown,_Washington,_D.C. "Chinatown, Washington, D.C.") section of the city. The [Washington D.C. Temple](/wiki/Washington_D.C._Temple "Washington D.C. Temple") is a large [Mormon](/wiki/Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints "Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints") [temple](/wiki/Temple_(Latter_Day_Saints) "Temple (Latter Day Saints)") located just outside the city in [Kensington, Maryland](/wiki/Kensington,_Maryland "Kensington, Maryland"). Viewable from the [Capital Beltway](/wiki/Capital_Beltway "Capital Beltway"), the temple is the tallest Mormon temple in existence and the third-largest by square footage.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-163)^^[\[157\]](#cite_note-164)^{#cite_ref-164}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

Main article: [Economy of the Washington metropolitan area](/wiki/Economy_of_the_Washington_metropolitan_area "Economy of the Washington metropolitan area")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Ec_05_%2826114196145%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Ec_05_%2826114196145%29_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ec_05_(26114196145)_(cropped).jpg) The [Eccles Building](/wiki/Eccles_Building "Eccles Building") on [Constitution Avenue](/wiki/Constitution_Avenue "Constitution Avenue"), home of the [Federal Reserve](/wiki/Federal_Reserve "Federal Reserve"), the [central bank](/wiki/Central_bank "Central bank") of the United States

As of 2023,^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Washington,_D.C.&action=edit)^ the [Washington metropolitan area](/wiki/Washington_metropolitan_area "Washington metropolitan area"), including the District of Columbia as well as parts of [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia"), [Maryland](/wiki/Maryland "Maryland"), and [West Virginia](/wiki/West_Virginia "West Virginia"), was one of the nation's largest metropolitan economies. Its growing and diversified economy has an increasing percentage of professional and business service jobs in addition to more traditional jobs rooted in tourism, entertainment, and government.^[\[158\]](#cite_note-165)^^\[*[obsolete source](/wiki/Wikipedia:AGE_MATTERS "Wikipedia:AGE MATTERS")*\]^{#cite_ref-165}

Between 2009 and 2016, [gross domestic product](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") per capita in Washington, D.C., consistently ranked at the very top among U.S. states.^[\[159\]](#cite_note-capita2009-166)^ In 2016, at $160,472, its GDP per capita was almost three times greater than that of [Massachusetts](/wiki/Massachusetts "Massachusetts"), which was ranked second in the nation (see [List of U.S. states and territories by GDP](/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_and_territories_by_GDP "List of U.S. states and territories by GDP")).^[\[159\]](#cite_note-capita2009-166)^ As of 2022^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Washington,_D.C.&action=edit)^, the metropolitan statistical area's unemployment rate was 3.1%, ranking 171 out of the 389 metropolitan areas as defined by the U.S. [Bureau of Economic Analysis](/wiki/Bureau_of_Economic_Analysis "Bureau of Economic Analysis").^[\[160\]](#cite_note-167)^ The District of Columbia itself had an unemployment rate of 4.6% during the same time period.^[\[161\]](#cite_note-168)^ In 2019, Washington, D.C., had the highest median household income in the U.S. at $92,266.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-169)^{#cite_ref-169}

According to the District's [comprehensive annual financial reports](/wiki/Comprehensive_annual_financial_report "Comprehensive annual financial report"), the top employers by number of employees in 2022 included [Georgetown University](/wiki/Georgetown_University "Georgetown University"), [Children's National Medical Center](/wiki/Children%27s_National_Medical_Center "Children's National Medical Center"), [Washington Hospital Center](/wiki/Washington_Hospital_Center "Washington Hospital Center"), [George Washington University](/wiki/George_Washington_University "George Washington University"), [American University](/wiki/American_University "American University"), [Georgetown University Hospital](/wiki/Georgetown_University_Hospital "Georgetown University Hospital"), [Booz Allen \& Hamilton](/wiki/Booz_Allen_%26_Hamilton "Booz Allen & Hamilton"), [Insperity](/wiki/Insperity "Insperity") PEO Services, [Universal Protection Service](/wiki/Universal_Protection_Service "Universal Protection Service"), [Howard University](/wiki/Howard_University "Howard University"), [Medstar Medical Group](/wiki/MedStar_Health "MedStar Health"), [George Washington University Hospital](/wiki/George_Washington_University_Hospital "George Washington University Hospital"), [Catholic University of America](/wiki/Catholic_University_of_America "Catholic University of America"), and [Sibley Memorial Hospital](/wiki/Sibley_Memorial_Hospital "Sibley Memorial Hospital").^[\[163\]](#cite_note-170)^{#cite_ref-170}  

### Federal government {#Federal_government}

Main article: [Federal government of the United States](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government of the United States")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Aerial_view_showing_top_of_Washington_Monument%2C_Washington%2C_D.C_LCCN2010630904_%28cropped%29.tiff/lossy-page1-220px-Aerial_view_showing_top_of_Washington_Monument%2C_Washington%2C_D.C_LCCN2010630904_%28cropped%29.tiff.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aerial_view_showing_top_of_Washington_Monument,_Washington,_D.C_LCCN2010630904_(cropped).tiff) [Federal Triangle](/wiki/Federal_Triangle "Federal Triangle"), a historic hub of [executive departments](/wiki/United_States_federal_executive_departments "United States federal executive departments") of the [U.S. federal government](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government of the United States")

As of July 2022, 25% of people employed in Washington, D.C., were employed by the federal government.^[\[164\]](#cite_note-171)^ Many of the region's residents are employed by companies and organizations that do work for the federal government, seek to [influence federal policy](/wiki/Lobbying_in_the_United_States "Lobbying in the United States"), or are otherwise related to its work, including [law firms](/wiki/Law_firm "Law firm"), [defense contractors](/wiki/Defense_contractor "Defense contractor"), [civilian contractors](/wiki/Independent_contractor "Independent contractor"), [nonprofit organizations](/wiki/Nonprofit_organization "Nonprofit organization"), [lobbying firms](/wiki/Lobbying_in_the_United_States "Lobbying in the United States"), [trade unions](/wiki/Trade_union "Trade union"), [industry trade groups](/wiki/Industry_trade_group "Industry trade group"), and [professional associations](/wiki/Professional_association "Professional association"), many of which have their headquarters in or near the city for proximity to the federal government.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-171}  

### Diplomacy {#Diplomacy}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/French_ambassador%27s_residence_-_Washington%2C_D.C..jpg/220px-French_ambassador%27s_residence_-_Washington%2C_D.C..jpg)](/wiki/File:French_ambassador%27s_residence_-_Washington,_D.C..jpg) The [French ambassador's residence](/wiki/French_ambassador%27s_residence_in_Washington,_D.C. "French ambassador's residence in Washington, D.C.") in the [Sheridan-Kalorama Historic District](/wiki/Sheridan-Kalorama_Historic_District "Sheridan-Kalorama Historic District")

As the national capital, Washington, D.C. hosts about 185 foreign missions, including embassies, ambassador's residences, and international cultural centers.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-172)^ Many are concentrated along a stretch of [Massachusetts Avenue](/wiki/Massachusetts_Avenue_(Washington,_D.C.) "Massachusetts Avenue (Washington, D.C.)") known informally as [Embassy Row](/wiki/Embassy_Row "Embassy Row").^[\[166\]](#cite_note-173)^ Washington, D.C. is one of the most culturally diverse cities in the world; it hosts a number of internationally themed festivals and events, often in collaboration with foreign missions or delegations.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ The city government maintains an Office of International Affairs to liaise with the diplomatic community and foreign delegations.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-174)^{#cite_ref-174}  

### Research and non-profit organizations {#Research_and_non-profit_organizations}

See also: [Category:Non-profit organizations based in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Category:Non-profit_organizations_based_in_Washington,_D.C. "Category:Non-profit organizations based in Washington, D.C.")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/%22The_Conservative_Sensibility%22_event_at_AEI.jpg/220px-%22The_Conservative_Sensibility%22_event_at_AEI.jpg)](/wiki/File:%22The_Conservative_Sensibility%22_event_at_AEI.jpg) A panel discussion at the [American Enterprise Institute](/wiki/American_Enterprise_Institute "American Enterprise Institute"), one of the city's many [think tanks](/wiki/Think_tank "Think tank")

Washington, D.C., is a leading center for national and international research organizations, especially [think tanks](/wiki/Think_tank "Think tank") engaged in public policy.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-175)^ As of 2020, 8% of the country's think tanks are based in the city, including many of the largest and most widely cited,^[\[169\]](#cite_note-176)^ including the [Carnegie Endowment for International Peace](/wiki/Carnegie_Endowment_for_International_Peace "Carnegie Endowment for International Peace"), [Center for Strategic and International Studies](/wiki/Center_for_Strategic_and_International_Studies "Center for Strategic and International Studies"), [Peterson Institute for International Economics](/wiki/Peterson_Institute_for_International_Economics "Peterson Institute for International Economics"), [The Heritage Foundation](/wiki/The_Heritage_Foundation "The Heritage Foundation"), and [Urban Institute](/wiki/Urban_Institute "Urban Institute").^[\[170\]](#cite_note-177)^{#cite_ref-177}

Washington, D.C. is home to many non-profit organizations that engage with issues of domestic and global importance by conducting advanced research, running programs, or public advocacy. Among these organizations are the [UN Foundation](/wiki/UN_Foundation "UN Foundation"), [Human Rights Campaign](/wiki/Human_Rights_Campaign "Human Rights Campaign"), [Amnesty International](/wiki/Amnesty_International "Amnesty International"), and the [National Endowment for Democracy](/wiki/National_Endowment_for_Democracy "National Endowment for Democracy").^[\[171\]](#cite_note-178)^ Major medical research institutions include the [MedStar Washington Hospital Center](/wiki/MedStar_Washington_Hospital_Center "MedStar Washington Hospital Center") and the [Children's National Medical Center](/wiki/Children%27s_National_Medical_Center "Children's National Medical Center").^[\[172\]](#cite_note-179)^{#cite_ref-179}

The city is the country's primary location for international development firms, many of which contract with the D.C.-based [United States Agency for International Development](/wiki/United_States_Agency_for_International_Development "United States Agency for International Development") (USAID), the U.S. federal government's aid agency. The [American Red Cross](/wiki/American_Red_Cross "American Red Cross"), a humanitarian agency focused on emergency relief, is also based in the city.^[\[173\]](#cite_note-180)^{#cite_ref-180}  

### Private sector {#Private_sector}

See also: [Category:Companies based in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Category:Companies_based_in_Washington,_D.C. "Category:Companies based in Washington, D.C.") and [Washington metropolitan area § Primary industries](/wiki/Washington_metropolitan_area#Primary_industries "Washington metropolitan area")

According to statistics compiled in 2011, four of the [largest 500 companies](/wiki/Fortune_500 "Fortune 500") in the country were based in Washington, D.C.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-181)^ In the 2023 [Global Financial Centres Index](/wiki/Global_Financial_Centres_Index "Global Financial Centres Index"), Washington was ranked as having the 8th most competitive financial center in the world, and fourth most competitive in the United States (after [New York City](/wiki/Economy_of_New_York_City "Economy of New York City"), [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco#Economy "San Francisco"), and [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles#Economy "Los Angeles")).^[\[175\]](#cite_note-182)^ Among the largest companies based in Washington, D.C., are [Fannie Mae](/wiki/Fannie_Mae "Fannie Mae"), [Amtrak](/wiki/Amtrak "Amtrak"), [Danaher Corporation](/wiki/Danaher_Corporation "Danaher Corporation"), [FTI Consulting](/wiki/FTI_Consulting "FTI Consulting"), and [Hogan Lovells](/wiki/Hogan_Lovells "Hogan Lovells").^[\[176\]](#cite_note-183)^^\[*[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")*\]^{#cite_ref-183}  

### Tourism {#Tourism}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/World_War_II_Memorial_Wade-47.JPG/220px-World_War_II_Memorial_Wade-47.JPG)](/wiki/File:World_War_II_Memorial_Wade-47.JPG) The [World War II Memorial](/wiki/World_War_II_Memorial "World War II Memorial"), one of many popular tourist sites located on the [National Mall](/wiki/National_Mall "National Mall")

Tourism is the city's second-largest industry, after the federal government. In 2012, some 18.9 million visitors contributed an estimated $4.8 billion to the local economy.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-tourism2012-184)^ In 2019, the city saw 24.6 million tourists, including 1.8 million from foreign countries, who collectively spent $8.15 billion during their stay.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-tourism2019-185)^ Tourism helps many of the region's other industries, such as lodging, food and beverage, entertainment, shopping, and transportation.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-tourism2019-185)^{#cite_ref-tourism2019_185-1}

The city and the larger [Washington metropolitan area](/wiki/Washington_metropolitan_area "Washington metropolitan area") have an array of attractions for tourists, including monuments, memorials, museums, sports events, and trails. Within the city, the [National Mall](/wiki/National_Mall "National Mall") serves as the center of the tourism industry. It is there that many of the city's museums and monuments are located. Adjacent to the mall sits the [Tidal Basin](/wiki/Tidal_Basin "Tidal Basin"), where several major national memorials and monuments are located, including the popular [Jefferson Memorial](/wiki/Jefferson_Memorial "Jefferson Memorial"). [Washington Union Station](/wiki/Washington_Union_Station "Washington Union Station") is a popular tourist spot with its multitude of restaurants and shops.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

Main article: [Culture of Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Culture_of_Washington,_D.C. "Culture of Washington, D.C.")
