### Arts {#Arts}

Main article: [Theater in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Theater_in_Washington,_D.C. "Theater in Washington, D.C.")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Moulin_Rouge_at_the_John_F._Kennedy_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts_audience_perspective.jpg/220px-Moulin_Rouge_at_the_John_F._Kennedy_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts_audience_perspective.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moulin_Rouge_at_the_John_F._Kennedy_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts_audience_perspective.jpg) A performance of *[Moulin Rouge!](/wiki/Moulin_Rouge!_(musical) "Moulin Rouge! (musical)")* at the [Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts "John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts")

Washington, D.C., is a national center for the arts, home to several concert halls and theaters. The [John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts "John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts") is home to the [National Symphony Orchestra](/wiki/National_Symphony_Orchestra_(United_States) "National Symphony Orchestra (United States)"), the [Washington National Opera](/wiki/Washington_National_Opera "Washington National Opera"), and the [Washington Ballet](/wiki/Washington_Ballet "Washington Ballet"). The [Kennedy Center Honors](/wiki/Kennedy_Center_Honors "Kennedy Center Honors") are awarded each year to those in the performing arts who have contributed greatly to the cultural life of the United States. This ceremony is often attended by the sitting [U.S. president](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States") and other dignitaries and celebrities.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-187)^ The Kennedy Center also awards the annual [Mark Twain Prize for American Humor](/wiki/Mark_Twain_Prize_for_American_Humor "Mark Twain Prize for American Humor").^[\[181\]](#cite_note-188)^{#cite_ref-188}

The historic [Ford's Theatre](/wiki/Ford%27s_Theatre "Ford's Theatre"), the site of the [assassination of President Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Assassination_of_Abraham_Lincoln "Assassination of Abraham Lincoln") on April 14, 1865, continues to function as a theatre and as a museum.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-189)^{#cite_ref-189}

The [Marine Barracks](/wiki/Marine_Barracks,_Washington,_D.C. "Marine Barracks, Washington, D.C.") near [Capitol Hill](/wiki/Capitol_Hill "Capitol Hill") houses the [United States Marine Band](/wiki/United_States_Marine_Band "United States Marine Band"); founded in 1798, it is the country's oldest professional musical organization.^[\[183\]](#cite_note-190)^ [American march composer](/wiki/American_march_music "American march music") and Washington-native [John Philip Sousa](/wiki/John_Philip_Sousa "John Philip Sousa") led the Marine Band from 1880 until 1892.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-191)^ Founded in 1925, the [United States Navy Band](/wiki/United_States_Navy_Band "United States Navy Band") has its headquarters at the [Washington Navy Yard](/wiki/Washington_Navy_Yard "Washington Navy Yard") and performs at official events and public concerts around the city.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-192)^{#cite_ref-192}

Founded in 1950, [Arena Stage](/wiki/Arena_Stage "Arena Stage") achieved national attention and spurred growth in the city's independent theater movement that now includes organizations such as the [Shakespeare Theatre Company](/wiki/Shakespeare_Theatre_Company "Shakespeare Theatre Company"), [Woolly Mammoth Theatre Company](/wiki/Woolly_Mammoth_Theatre_Company "Woolly Mammoth Theatre Company"), and the [Studio Theatre](/wiki/Studio_Theatre_(Washington,_D.C.) "Studio Theatre (Washington, D.C.)").^[\[186\]](#cite_note-193)^ Arena Stage reopened after a renovation and expansion in the city's emerging [Southwest waterfront area](/wiki/Southwest_Waterfront,_Washington,_D.C. "Southwest Waterfront, Washington, D.C.") in 2010.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-194)^ The [GALA Hispanic Theatre](/wiki/GALA_Hispanic_Theatre "GALA Hispanic Theatre"), now housed in the historic [Tivoli Theatre](/wiki/Tivoli_Theatre_(Washington,_D.C.) "Tivoli Theatre (Washington, D.C.)") in [Columbia Heights](/wiki/Columbia_Heights_(Washington,_D.C.) "Columbia Heights (Washington, D.C.)"), was founded in 1976 and is a National Center for the Latino Performing Arts.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-195)^{#cite_ref-195}

Other performing arts spaces in the city include the [Andrew W. Mellon Auditorium](/wiki/Andrew_W._Mellon_Auditorium "Andrew W. Mellon Auditorium") in [Federal Triangle](/wiki/Federal_Triangle "Federal Triangle"), the [Atlas Performing Arts Center](/wiki/Atlas_Performing_Arts_Center "Atlas Performing Arts Center") on [H Street](/wiki/H_Street_(Washington,_D.C.) "H Street (Washington, D.C.)"), the [Carter Barron Amphitheater](/wiki/Carter_Barron_Amphitheater "Carter Barron Amphitheater") in [Rock Creek Park](/wiki/Rock_Creek_Park "Rock Creek Park"), [Constitution Hall](/wiki/DAR_Constitution_Hall "DAR Constitution Hall") in [Downtown](/wiki/Downtown,_Washington,_D.C. "Downtown, Washington, D.C."), the [Keegan Theatre](/wiki/Keegan_Theatre "Keegan Theatre") in [Dupont Circle](/wiki/Dupont_Circle "Dupont Circle"), the [Lisner Auditorium](/wiki/Lisner_Auditorium "Lisner Auditorium") in [Foggy Bottom](/wiki/Foggy_Bottom "Foggy Bottom"), the [Sylvan Theater](/wiki/National_Sylvan_Theater "National Sylvan Theater") on the [National Mall](/wiki/National_Mall "National Mall"), and the [Warner Theatre](/wiki/Warner_Theatre_(Washington,_D.C.) "Warner Theatre (Washington, D.C.)") in [Penn Quarter](/wiki/Penn_Quarter "Penn Quarter").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ The [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre_(Washington,_D.C.) "National Theatre (Washington, D.C.)") in Downtown D.C. is the second-oldest continuously operating theater in the United States, having first opened in 1835.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-196)^{#cite_ref-196}

The [U Street Corridor](/wiki/U_Street_Corridor "U Street Corridor") in Northwest D.C., once known as "Washington's Black Broadway", is home to institutions like [Howard Theatre](/wiki/Howard_Theatre "Howard Theatre") and [Lincoln Theatre](/wiki/Lincoln_Theatre_(Washington,_D.C.) "Lincoln Theatre (Washington, D.C.)"), which hosted music legends such as Washington-native [Duke Ellington](/wiki/Duke_Ellington "Duke Ellington"), [John Coltrane](/wiki/John_Coltrane "John Coltrane"), and [Miles Davis](/wiki/Miles_Davis "Miles Davis").^[\[190\]](#cite_note-ustreet-197)^ Just east of U Street is [Shaw](/wiki/Shaw_(Washington,_D.C.) "Shaw (Washington, D.C.)"), which also served as a major cultural center during the [jazz age](/wiki/Jazz_age "Jazz age"). Intersecting with U Street is [Fourteenth Street](/wiki/Fourteenth_Street_(Washington,_D.C.) "Fourteenth Street (Washington, D.C.)"), which was an extension of the U Street cultural corridor during the 1920s through the 1960s. The collection of Fourteenth Street, U Street, and Shaw was the location of the [Black Renaissance in D.C.](/wiki/Black_Renaissance_in_D.C. "Black Renaissance in D.C."), which was part of the larger [Harlem Renaissance](/wiki/Harlem_Renaissance "Harlem Renaissance"). Today, the area starting at Fourteenth Street downtown going north through U Street and east to Shaw boasts a high concentration of bars, restaurants, and theaters, and is among the city's most notable cultural and artistic areas.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-ustreet_197-0}

The [Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association](/wiki/Washington_D.C._Area_Film_Critics_Association "Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association") (WAFCA), a group of more than 65 film critics, holds an annual awards ceremony.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-aboutwafca-198)^{#cite_ref-aboutwafca_198-0}  

### Music {#Music}

Main article: [Music of Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Music_of_Washington,_D.C. "Music of Washington, D.C.")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Chuck_Brown_%285318700369%29.jpg/220px-Chuck_Brown_%285318700369%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chuck_Brown_(5318700369).jpg) [Chuck Brown](/wiki/Chuck_Brown "Chuck Brown") performing [go-go](/wiki/Go-go "Go-go") music

[Columbia Records](/wiki/Columbia_Records "Columbia Records"), a major music record label in the US, was founded in Washington, D.C. in 1889.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-199)^^: 105^{#cite_ref-199}

The city grew into being one of America's most important music cities in the early [jazz age](/wiki/Jazz_age "Jazz age"). [Duke Ellington](/wiki/Duke_Ellington "Duke Ellington"), among the most prominent jazz composers and musicians of his time, was born and raised in Washington, and began his music career in the city. The center of the city's jazz scene during those years was [U street](/wiki/U_Street_(Washington,_D.C.) "U Street (Washington, D.C.)") and [Shaw](/wiki/Shaw_(Washington,_D.C.) "Shaw (Washington, D.C.)"). Among the city's major jazz locations were the [Lincoln Theatre](/wiki/Lincoln_Theatre_(Washington,_D.C.) "Lincoln Theatre (Washington, D.C.)") and the [Howard Theatre](/wiki/Howard_Theatre "Howard Theatre").^[\[193\]](#cite_note-200)^{#cite_ref-200}

Washington has its own native music genre called [go-go](/wiki/Go-go "Go-go"); a post-funk, percussion-driven flavor of rhythm and blues that was popularized in the late 1970s by D.C. band leader [Chuck Brown](/wiki/Chuck_Brown "Chuck Brown").^[\[194\]](#cite_note-201)^{#cite_ref-201}

The district is an important center for [indie culture and music](/wiki/Indie_music_scene "Indie music scene") in the United States. The DC-based label [Dischord Records](/wiki/Dischord_Records "Dischord Records"), formed by [Ian MacKaye](/wiki/Ian_MacKaye "Ian MacKaye"), frontman of [Fugazi](/wiki/Fugazi "Fugazi"), was one of the most crucial independent labels in the genesis of 1980s punk and eventually indie rock in the 1990s.^[\[195\]](#cite_note-202)^ Modern [alternative](/wiki/Alternative_rock "Alternative rock") and indie music venues like [The Black Cat](/wiki/Black_Cat_(Washington,_D.C._nightclub) "Black Cat (Washington, D.C. nightclub)") and the [9:30 Club](/wiki/9:30_Club "9:30 Club") bring popular acts to the U Street area.^[\[196\]](#cite_note-203)^ The hardcore punk scene in the city, known as [D.C. hardcore](/wiki/Washington,_D.C._hardcore "Washington, D.C. hardcore"), is an important genre of D.C.'s contemporary music scene. Starting in the 1970s and flourishing in the [Adams Morgan](/wiki/Adams_Morgan "Adams Morgan") neighborhood, it is considered to be one of the most influential punk music movements in the country.^[\[197\]](#cite_note-SG_13DCHC-204)^{#cite_ref-SG_13DCHC_204-0}  

### Cuisine {#Cuisine}

See also: [List of Michelin starred restaurants in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/List_of_Michelin_starred_restaurants_in_Washington,_D.C. "List of Michelin starred restaurants in Washington, D.C.")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Ethiopian_vegetarian_sampler.jpg/220px-Ethiopian_vegetarian_sampler.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ethiopian_vegetarian_sampler.jpg) [Beyaynetu](/wiki/Beyaynetu "Beyaynetu") served at Das Ethiopian Cuisine on 28th Street [Northwest](/wiki/Northwest_(Washington,_D.C.) "Northwest (Washington, D.C.)"), one of the city's [Ethiopian cuisine](/wiki/Ethiopian_cuisine "Ethiopian cuisine") restaurants

Washington, D.C., is rich in fine and casual dining; some consider it among the country's best cities for dining.^[\[198\]](#cite_note-205)^ The city has a diverse range of [restaurants](/wiki/Restaurant "Restaurant"), including a wide variety of international cuisines. The city's [Chinatown](/wiki/Chinatown_(Washington,_D.C.) "Chinatown (Washington, D.C.)"), for example, has more than a dozen Chinese-style restaurants. The city also has many Middle Eastern, European, African, Asian, and Latin American cuisine options.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ D.C. is known as one of the best cities in the world for [Ethiopian cuisine](/wiki/Ethiopian_cuisine "Ethiopian cuisine"), due largely to [Ethiopian immigrants](/wiki/Ethiopians_in_Washington,_D.C. "Ethiopians in Washington, D.C.") who arrived in the 20th century.^[\[199\]](#cite_note-206)^ A part of the [Shaw](/wiki/Shaw_(Washington,_D.C.) "Shaw (Washington, D.C.)") neighborhood in central D.C. is known as "Little Ethiopia" and has a high concentration of Ethiopian restaurants and shops.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-207)^ The diversity of cuisine is also reflected in the city's many [food trucks](/wiki/Food_truck "Food truck"), which are particularly heavily concentrated along the [National Mall](/wiki/National_Mall "National Mall"), which has few other dining options.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-207}

Among the most notable Washington, D.C.-born foods is the [half-smoke](/wiki/Half-smoke "Half-smoke"), a half-beef, half-pork sausage placed in a [hotdog](/wiki/Hotdog "Hotdog")-style bun and topped with onion, chili, and cheese.^[\[201\]](#cite_note-208)^ The city is also the birthplace of [mumbo sauce](/wiki/Mumbo_sauce "Mumbo sauce"), a [condiment](/wiki/Condiment "Condiment") similar to [barbecue sauce](/wiki/Barbecue_sauce "Barbecue sauce") but sweeter in flavor, often used on meat and [french fries](/wiki/French_fries "French fries").^[\[202\]](#cite_note-209)^^[\[203\]](#cite_note-210)^ Washington, D.C. is known for popularizing the [jumbo slice](/wiki/Jumbo_slice "Jumbo slice") pizza, a large [New York-style pizza](/wiki/New_York-style_pizza "New York-style pizza")^[\[204\]](#cite_note-Barrett-211)^^[\[205\]](#cite_note-Stern-212)^^[\[206\]](#cite_note-213)^ with roots in the [Adams Morgan](/wiki/Adams_Morgan "Adams Morgan") neighborhood.^[\[207\]](#cite_note-214)^{#cite_ref-214}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/2020.03.19_DC_People_and_Places%2C_Washington%2C_DC_USA_080_30017_%2849679399691%29.jpg/220px-2020.03.19_DC_People_and_Places%2C_Washington%2C_DC_USA_080_30017_%2849679399691%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:2020.03.19_DC_People_and_Places,_Washington,_DC_USA_080_30017_(49679399691).jpg) [Ben's Chili Bowl](/wiki/Ben%27s_Chili_Bowl "Ben's Chili Bowl") on [U Street](/wiki/U_Street_(Washington,_D.C.) "U Street (Washington, D.C.)"), known for its [half-smoke](/wiki/Half-smoke "Half-smoke"), a historic staple of the city's cuisine

Among the city's signature restaurants is [Ben's Chili Bowl](/wiki/Ben%27s_Chili_Bowl "Ben's Chili Bowl"), located on [U Street](/wiki/U_Street_(Washington,_D.C.) "U Street (Washington, D.C.)") since its founding in 1958. The restaurant rose to prominence as a peaceful escape during the violent [1968 race riots](/wiki/1968_Washington,_D.C.,_riots "1968 Washington, D.C., riots") in the city. Famous for its [chili dogs](/wiki/Chili_dog "Chili dog") and half-smokes, it has been visited by numerous presidents and celebrities over the years.^[\[208\]](#cite_note-215)^ The [Georgetown Cupcake](/wiki/Georgetown_Cupcake "Georgetown Cupcake") bakery became famous through its appearance on the reality T.V. show [DC Cupcakes](/wiki/DC_Cupcakes "DC Cupcakes"). Another culinary hotspot is [Union Market](/wiki/Union_Market "Union Market") in [Northeast D.C.](/wiki/Northeast_D.C. "Northeast D.C."), a former farmer's market and wholesale that now houses a large, gourmet [food hall](/wiki/Food_hall "Food hall").^[\[209\]](#cite_note-Lerner-216)^{#cite_ref-Lerner_216-0}

As of 2024, 25 restaurants (including one in Virginia, [The Inn at Little Washington](/wiki/The_Inn_at_Little_Washington "The Inn at Little Washington")) have received stars in the D.C. [Michelin Guide](/wiki/Michelin_Guide "Michelin Guide").^[\[210\]](#cite_note-217)^ This represents the most starred restaurants *per capita* for any U.S. city, and the third-most in the world.^[\[211\]](#cite_note-218)^ Several celebrity chefs have opened restaurants in the city, including [José Andrés](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Andr%C3%A9s "José Andrés"),^[\[212\]](#cite_note-219)^ [Kwame Onwuachi](/wiki/Kwame_Onwuachi "Kwame Onwuachi"),^[\[213\]](#cite_note-220)^ [Gordon Ramsay](/wiki/Gordon_Ramsay "Gordon Ramsay"),^[\[214\]](#cite_note-221)^^[\[215\]](#cite_note-222)^ and previously [Michel Richard](/wiki/Michel_Richard "Michel Richard").^[\[216\]](#cite_note-223)^{#cite_ref-223}  

### Museums {#Museums}

See also: [List of museums in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Washington,_D.C. "List of museums in Washington, D.C.")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Smithsonian_Institution_National_Museum_of_Natural_History_%287508870948%29.jpg/220px-Smithsonian_Institution_National_Museum_of_Natural_History_%287508870948%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Smithsonian_Institution_National_Museum_of_Natural_History_(7508870948).jpg) The [National Museum of Natural History](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Natural_History "National Museum of Natural History"), the [third-most visited museum in the U.S. in 2023](/wiki/List_of_most-visited_museums_in_the_United_States "List of most-visited museums in the United States"), with 4.4 million visitors [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/National_Gallery_of_Art.jpg/220px-National_Gallery_of_Art.jpg)](/wiki/File:National_Gallery_of_Art.jpg) The [National Gallery of Art](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Art "National Gallery of Art"), the [fourth-most visited art museum in the United States](/wiki/List_of_most-visited_museums_in_the_United_States "List of most-visited museums in the United States") in 2023 with nearly four million visitors

Washington, D.C. is home to several of the [country's](/wiki/List_of_most-visited_museums_in_the_United_States "List of most-visited museums in the United States") and [world's most visited museums](/wiki/List_of_most-visited_museums "List of most-visited museums"). In 2022, the [National Museum of Natural History](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Natural_History "National Museum of Natural History") and the [National Gallery of Art](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Art "National Gallery of Art") were the two most visited museums in the country. Overall, Washington had eight of the 28 most visited museums in the U.S. in 2022. That year, the National Museum of Natural History was the fifth-most-visited museum in the world; the National Gallery of Art was the eleventh.^[\[217\]](#cite_note-teacom-224)^{#cite_ref-teacom_224-0}  

#### Smithsonian museums {#Smithsonian_museums}

See also: [List of Smithsonian museums](/wiki/List_of_Smithsonian_museums "List of Smithsonian museums")

The [Smithsonian Institution](/wiki/Smithsonian_Institution "Smithsonian Institution"), an educational foundation chartered by [Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") in 1846 and the world's largest research and museum complex, is responsible for maintaining most of the city's official museums and galleries.^[\[218\]](#cite_note-225)^ The U.S. government partially funds the Smithsonian, and its collections are open to the public free of charge.^[\[219\]](#cite_note-226)^ The Smithsonian's locations had a combined total of 30 million visits in 2013. The most visited museum is the [National Museum of Natural History](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Natural_History "National Museum of Natural History") on the National Mall.^[\[220\]](#cite_note-227)^ Other Smithsonian Institution museums and galleries on the Mall include the [National Air and Space Museum](/wiki/National_Air_and_Space_Museum "National Air and Space Museum"); the [National Museum of African Art](/wiki/National_Museum_of_African_Art "National Museum of African Art"); the [National Museum of American History](/wiki/National_Museum_of_American_History "National Museum of American History"); the [National Museum of the American Indian](/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_American_Indian "National Museum of the American Indian"); the [Sackler](/wiki/Arthur_M._Sackler_Gallery "Arthur M. Sackler Gallery") and [Freer](/wiki/Freer_Gallery_of_Art "Freer Gallery of Art") galleries, which focus on Asian art and culture; the [Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden](/wiki/Hirshhorn_Museum_and_Sculpture_Garden "Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden"); the [Arts and Industries Building](/wiki/Arts_and_Industries_Building "Arts and Industries Building"); the [S. Dillon Ripley Center](/wiki/S._Dillon_Ripley_Center "S. Dillon Ripley Center"); and the [Smithsonian Institution Building](/wiki/Smithsonian_Institution_Building "Smithsonian Institution Building"), which serves as the institution's headquarters.^[\[221\]](#cite_note-SI-228)^{#cite_ref-SI_228-0}

The [Smithsonian American Art Museum](/wiki/Smithsonian_American_Art_Museum "Smithsonian American Art Museum") and the [National Portrait Gallery](/wiki/National_Portrait_Gallery_(United_States) "National Portrait Gallery (United States)") are housed in the [Old Patent Office Building](/wiki/Old_Patent_Office_Building "Old Patent Office Building") near Washington's [Chinatown](/wiki/Chinatown,_Washington,_D.C. "Chinatown, Washington, D.C.").^[\[222\]](#cite_note-229)^ [Renwick Gallery](/wiki/Renwick_Gallery "Renwick Gallery") is part of the Smithsonian American Art Museum and is located in a separate building near the [White House](/wiki/White_House "White House"). Other Smithsonian museums and galleries include [Anacostia Community Museum](/wiki/Anacostia_Museum "Anacostia Museum") in Southeast Washington, the [National Postal Museum](/wiki/National_Postal_Museum "National Postal Museum") near [Washington Union Station](/wiki/Washington_Union_Station "Washington Union Station"), and the [National Zoo](/wiki/National_Zoological_Park_(United_States) "National Zoological Park (United States)") in [Woodley Park](/wiki/Woodley_Park,_Washington,_D.C. "Woodley Park, Washington, D.C.").^[\[221\]](#cite_note-SI-228)^{#cite_ref-SI_228-1}  

#### Other museums {#Other_museums}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/National_law_enforcement_officers_memorial.jpg/220px-National_law_enforcement_officers_memorial.jpg)](/wiki/File:National_law_enforcement_officers_memorial.jpg) The [National Building Museum](/wiki/National_Building_Museum "National Building Museum")

The [National Gallery of Art](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Art "National Gallery of Art") is on the National Mall near the Capitol and features American and European artworks. The U.S. government owns the gallery and its collections. However, they are not a part of the Smithsonian Institution.^[\[223\]](#cite_note-230)^ The [National Building Museum](/wiki/National_Building_Museum "National Building Museum"), which occupies the former Pension Building near [Judiciary Square](/wiki/Judiciary_Square,_Washington,_D.C. "Judiciary Square, Washington, D.C."), was chartered by Congress and hosts exhibits on architecture, urban planning, and design.^[\[224\]](#cite_note-231)^ The [Botanic Garden](/wiki/United_States_Botanic_Garden "United States Botanic Garden") is a [botanical garden](/wiki/Botanical_garden "Botanical garden") and museum operated by the U.S. Congress that is open to the public.^[\[225\]](#cite_note-232)^{#cite_ref-232}

There are several private art museums in Washington, D.C., that house major collections and exhibits open to the public, such as the [National Museum of Women in the Arts](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Women_in_the_Arts "National Museum of Women in the Arts") and [The Phillips Collection](/wiki/The_Phillips_Collection "The Phillips Collection") in [Dupont Circle](/wiki/Dupont_Circle,_Washington,_D.C. "Dupont Circle, Washington, D.C."), the first museum of modern art in the United States.^[\[226\]](#cite_note-233)^ Other private museums in Washington include the [O Street Museum](/wiki/O_Street_Museum "O Street Museum"), the [International Spy Museum](/wiki/International_Spy_Museum "International Spy Museum"), the [National Geographic Society](/wiki/National_Geographic_Society "National Geographic Society") Museum, and the [Museum of the Bible](/wiki/Museum_of_the_Bible "Museum of the Bible"). The [United States Holocaust Memorial Museum](/wiki/United_States_Holocaust_Memorial_Museum "United States Holocaust Memorial Museum") near the National Mall maintains exhibits, documentation, and artifacts related to the [Holocaust](/wiki/The_Holocaust "The Holocaust").^[\[227\]](#cite_note-234)^{#cite_ref-234}  

### Landmarks {#Landmarks}

See also: [List of National Historic Landmarks in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/List_of_National_Historic_Landmarks_in_Washington,_D.C. "List of National Historic Landmarks in Washington, D.C.") and [National Register of Historic Places listings in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places_listings_in_Washington,_D.C. "National Register of Historic Places listings in Washington, D.C.")  

#### National Mall and Tidal Basin {#National_Mall_and_Tidal_Basin}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Aerial_view_National_Mall_12_2014_DC_711.JPG/220px-Aerial_view_National_Mall_12_2014_DC_711.JPG)](/wiki/File:Aerial_view_National_Mall_12_2014_DC_711.JPG) [National Mall](/wiki/National_Mall "National Mall"), a landscaped park extending from the [Lincoln Memorial](/wiki/Lincoln_Memorial "Lincoln Memorial") to the [United States Capitol](/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Vietnam_Veterans_Memorial_reflection.jpg/220px-Vietnam_Veterans_Memorial_reflection.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vietnam_Veterans_Memorial_reflection.jpg) The [Vietnam Veterans Memorial](/wiki/Vietnam_Veterans_Memorial "Vietnam Veterans Memorial"), a two-acre (8,100 m^2^) site featuring two [black granite](/wiki/Black_granite "Black granite") walls engraved with the names of those service members who died or remain missing in the [Vietnam War](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War") designed by [Maya Lin](/wiki/Maya_Lin "Maya Lin"), was initially controversial for its lack of heroic iconography, a departure from earlier memorial designs.

The [National Mall](/wiki/National_Mall "National Mall") is a park near [Downtown Washington](/wiki/Downtown_(Washington,_D.C.) "Downtown (Washington, D.C.)") that stretches nearly two miles from the [Lincoln Memorial](/wiki/Lincoln_Memorial "Lincoln Memorial") to the [United States Capitol](/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol"). The mall often hosts [political protests](/wiki/List_of_protest_marches_on_Washington,_D.C. "List of protest marches on Washington, D.C."), concerts, festivals, and [presidential inaugurations](/wiki/United_States_presidential_inauguration "United States presidential inauguration"). The Capitol grounds host the *[National Memorial Day Concert](/wiki/National_Memorial_Day_Concert "National Memorial Day Concert")* , held each [Memorial Day](/wiki/Memorial_Day "Memorial Day"), and *[A Capitol Fourth](/wiki/A_Capitol_Fourth "A Capitol Fourth")* , a concert held each [Independence Day](/wiki/Independence_Day_(United_States) "Independence Day (United States)"). Both concerts are broadcast across the country on [PBS](/wiki/PBS "PBS"). In the evening on the Fourth of July, the park hosts a large [fireworks](/wiki/Fireworks "Fireworks") show.^[\[228\]](#cite_note-235)^{#cite_ref-235}

The [Washington Monument](/wiki/Washington_Monument "Washington Monument") and the [Jefferson Pier](/wiki/Jefferson_Pier "Jefferson Pier") are near the center of the mall, south of the [White House](/wiki/White_House "White House"). Directly northwest of the Washington Monument is [Constitution Gardens](/wiki/Constitution_Gardens "Constitution Gardens"), which includes a garden, park, pond, and a [memorial to the signers](/wiki/Memorial_to_the_56_Signers_of_the_Declaration_of_Independence "Memorial to the 56 Signers of the Declaration of Independence") of the [United States Declaration of Independence](/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence "United States Declaration of Independence").^[\[229\]](#cite_note-236)^ Just north of Constitution Gardens is the [Lockkeeper's House](/wiki/Lockkeeper%27s_House,_C_%26_O_Canal_Extension "Lockkeeper's House, C & O Canal Extension"), which is the second-oldest building on the mall after the White House. The house is operated by the [National Park Service](/wiki/National_Park_Service "National Park Service") (NPS) and is open to the public. Also on the mall is the [National World War II Memorial](/wiki/National_World_War_II_Memorial "National World War II Memorial") at the east end of the [Lincoln Memorial Reflecting Pool](/wiki/Lincoln_Memorial_Reflecting_Pool "Lincoln Memorial Reflecting Pool"); the [Korean War Veterans Memorial](/wiki/Korean_War_Veterans_Memorial "Korean War Veterans Memorial"); and the [Vietnam Veterans Memorial](/wiki/Vietnam_Veterans_Memorial "Vietnam Veterans Memorial").^[\[230\]](#cite_note-nama-237)^{#cite_ref-nama_237-0}

South of the mall is the [Tidal Basin](/wiki/Tidal_Basin_(District_of_Columbia) "Tidal Basin (District of Columbia)"), a human-made reservoir surrounded by pedestrian paths lined by Japanese cherry trees. Every spring, millions of cherry blossoms bloom, attracting visitors from across the world as part of the annual [National Cherry Blossom Festival](/wiki/National_Cherry_Blossom_Festival "National Cherry Blossom Festival").^[\[231\]](#cite_note-238)^ The [Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial](/wiki/Franklin_Delano_Roosevelt_Memorial "Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial"), [George Mason Memorial](/wiki/George_Mason_Memorial "George Mason Memorial"), [Jefferson Memorial](/wiki/Jefferson_Memorial "Jefferson Memorial"), [Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial](/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr._Memorial "Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial"), and the [District of Columbia War Memorial](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_War_Memorial "District of Columbia War Memorial") are around the Tidal Basin.^[\[230\]](#cite_note-nama-237)^{#cite_ref-nama_237-1}  

#### Other landmarks {#Other_landmarks}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/-i---i-_%2852380995447%29.jpg/220px--i---i-_%2852380995447%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:-i---i-_(52380995447).jpg) Protesters in front of the [U.S. Supreme Court Building](/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court_Building "United States Supreme Court Building") in June 2022

Numerous historic landmarks are located outside the [National Mall](/wiki/National_Mall "National Mall"). Among these are the [Old Post Office](/wiki/Old_Post_Office_(Washington,_D.C.) "Old Post Office (Washington, D.C.)"),^[\[232\]](#cite_note-239)^ the [Treasury Building](/wiki/Treasury_Building_(Washington,_D.C.) "Treasury Building (Washington, D.C.)"),^[\[233\]](#cite_note-240)^ [Old Patent Office Building](/wiki/Old_Patent_Office_Building "Old Patent Office Building"),^[\[234\]](#cite_note-241)^ the [National Cathedral](/wiki/National_Cathedral "National Cathedral"),^[\[235\]](#cite_note-242)^ the [Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception](/wiki/Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_the_Immaculate_Conception "Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception"),^[\[236\]](#cite_note-243)^ the [National World War I Memorial](/wiki/National_World_War_I_Memorial_(Washington,_D.C.) "National World War I Memorial (Washington, D.C.)"),^[\[237\]](#cite_note-244)^ the [Frederick Douglass National Historic Site](/wiki/Frederick_Douglass_National_Historic_Site "Frederick Douglass National Historic Site"),^[\[238\]](#cite_note-245)^ [Lincoln's Cottage](/wiki/Lincoln%27s_Cottage "Lincoln's Cottage"),^[\[239\]](#cite_note-246)^ the [Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial](/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower_Memorial "Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial"), and the [United States Navy Memorial](/wiki/United_States_Navy_Memorial "United States Navy Memorial").^[\[240\]](#cite_note-247)^ [The Octagon House](/wiki/The_Octagon_House "The Octagon House"), which was the building that President [James Madison](/wiki/James_Madison "James Madison") and his administration moved into following the burning of the White House during the [War of 1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812"), is now a historic museum and popular tourist destination.^[\[241\]](#cite_note-248)^{#cite_ref-248}

The [National Archives](/wiki/National_Archives_and_Records_Administration "National Archives and Records Administration") is headquartered in a [building](/wiki/National_Archives_Building "National Archives Building") just north of the National Mall and houses thousands of documents important to American history, including the [Declaration of Independence](/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence "United States Declaration of Independence"), the [Constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_States "Constitution of the United States"), and the [Bill of Rights](/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights "United States Bill of Rights").^[\[242\]](#cite_note-249)^ Located in three buildings on Capitol Hill, the [Library of Congress](/wiki/Library_of_Congress "Library of Congress") is the largest library complex in the world with a collection of more than 147 million books, manuscripts, and other materials.^[\[243\]](#cite_note-250)^ The [United States Supreme Court](/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court "United States Supreme Court") is located immediately north of the Library of Congress. The [United States Supreme Court Building](/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court_Building "United States Supreme Court Building") was completed in 1935; before then, the court held sessions in the [Old Senate Chamber](/wiki/Old_Senate_Chamber "Old Senate Chamber") of the Capitol.^[\[244\]](#cite_note-251)^{#cite_ref-251}

[Chinatown](/wiki/Chinatown_(Washington,_D.C.) "Chinatown (Washington, D.C.)"), located just north of the National Mall, houses [Capital One Arena](/wiki/Capital_One_Arena "Capital One Arena"), which serves as the home arena to the [Washington Capitals](/wiki/Washington_Capitals "Washington Capitals") of the [National Hockey League](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League") and the [Washington Wizards](/wiki/Washington_Wizards "Washington Wizards") of the [National Basketball Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball Association"), and serves as the city's primary indoor entertainment arena. Chinatown includes several Chinese restaurants and shops. The [Friendship Archway](/wiki/Friendship_Archway_(Washington,_D.C.) "Friendship Archway (Washington, D.C.)") is one of the largest Chinese ceremonial archways outside of [China](/wiki/China "China") and bears the Chinese characters for "Chinatown" below its roof.^[\[245\]](#cite_note-252)^{#cite_ref-252}

The [Southwest Waterfront](/wiki/Southwest_Waterfront "Southwest Waterfront") along the Potomac River has been redeveloped in recent years and now serves as a popular cultural center. [The Wharf](/wiki/The_Wharf_(Washington,_D.C.) "The Wharf (Washington, D.C.)"), as it is called, contains the city's historic [Maine Avenue Fish Market](/wiki/Maine_Avenue_Fish_Market "Maine Avenue Fish Market"). This is the oldest fish market currently in operation in the entire United States.^[\[246\]](#cite_note-253)^ The Wharf also has many hotels, residential buildings, restaurants, shops, parks, piers, docks and marinas, and live music venues.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-wapo1-119)^^[\[118\]](#cite_note-wtop1-120)^{#cite_ref-wtop1_120-1}

As a result of its central role in United States history, the District of Columbia has many sites listed on the [National Register of Historic Places](/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places "National Register of Historic Places").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^  

Parks {#Parks}
--------------

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Pine_Trail_-_Flickr_-_treegrow_%281%29.jpg/220px-Pine_Trail_-_Flickr_-_treegrow_%281%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pine_Trail_-_Flickr_-_treegrow_(1).jpg) [Rock Creek Park](/wiki/Rock_Creek_Park "Rock Creek Park"), the city's largest park, stretches across [Northwest](/wiki/Northwest_(Washington,_D.C.) "Northwest (Washington, D.C.)"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Fountain_at_Meridian_Hill_Park_%28cropped2%29.jpg/220px-Fountain_at_Meridian_Hill_Park_%28cropped2%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fountain_at_Meridian_Hill_Park_(cropped2).jpg) The *[Cascading Waterfall](/wiki/Cascading_Waterfall "Cascading Waterfall")* at [Meridian Hill Park](/wiki/Meridian_Hill_Park "Meridian Hill Park") in [Meridian Hill](/wiki/Meridian_Hill "Meridian Hill")

There are many parks, gardens, squares, and circles throughout Washington. The city has 683 parks and greenspaces, comprising almost a quarter of its land area.^[\[247\]](#cite_note-254)^ Consequently, 99% of residents live within a 10-minute walk of a park.^[\[248\]](#cite_note-:0-255)^ According to the nonprofit [Trust for Public Land](/wiki/Trust_for_Public_Land "Trust for Public Land"), Washington ranked first among the 100 largest U.S. cities for its public parks, based on indicators such as accessibility, the share of land reserved for parks, and the amount invested in green spaces.^[\[248\]](#cite_note-:0-255)^{#cite_ref-:0_255-1}

[Rock Creek Park](/wiki/Rock_Creek_Park "Rock Creek Park"), located in Northwest D.C., is the largest park in the city and is administered by the [National Park Service](/wiki/National_Park_Service "National Park Service").^[\[249\]](#cite_note-256)^ Located on the northern side of the White House, [Lafayette Square](/wiki/Lafayette_Square_(Washington,_D.C.) "Lafayette Square (Washington, D.C.)") is a historic public square. Named after [the Marquis de Lafayette](/wiki/Gilbert_du_Motier,_Marquis_de_Lafayette "Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette"), a Frenchman who served as a commander during the [American Revolutionary War](/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American Revolutionary War"), the square has been the site of many protests, marches, and speeches. The houses bordering Lafayette Square have served as the home to many notable figures, such as [First Lady](/wiki/First_Lady_of_the_United_States "First Lady of the United States") [Dolley Madison](/wiki/Dolley_Madison "Dolley Madison") and [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln")'s [Secretary of State](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State "United States Secretary of State") [William H. Seward](/wiki/William_H._Seward "William H. Seward"), who was stabbed by an intruder in his Lafayette Square house on the evening of [President Lincoln's assassination](/wiki/Assassination_of_Abraham_Lincoln "Assassination of Abraham Lincoln").^[\[250\]](#cite_note-257)^ Located next to the square and on [Pennsylvania Avenue](/wiki/Pennsylvania_Avenue "Pennsylvania Avenue") across from the White House is the [Blair House](/wiki/Blair_House "Blair House"), which serves as the primary [state guest house](/wiki/State_guest_house "State guest house") for the [U.S. president](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States").^[\[251\]](#cite_note-258)^{#cite_ref-258}

There are several river islands in Washington, D.C., including [Theodore Roosevelt Island](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt_Island "Theodore Roosevelt Island") in the [Potomac River](/wiki/Potomac_River "Potomac River"), which hosts the [Theodore Roosevelt National Memorial](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt_Island#National_memorial "Theodore Roosevelt Island") and a number of trails.^[\[252\]](#cite_note-259)^ [Columbia Island](/wiki/Columbia_Island_(Washington,_D.C.) "Columbia Island (Washington, D.C.)"), also in the Potomac, is home to the [Lyndon Baines Johnson Memorial Grove](/wiki/Lyndon_Baines_Johnson_Memorial_Grove_on_the_Potomac "Lyndon Baines Johnson Memorial Grove on the Potomac"), the [Navy -- Merchant Marine Memorial](/wiki/Navy_%E2%80%93_Merchant_Marine_Memorial "Navy – Merchant Marine Memorial"), and a marina. [Kingman Island](/wiki/Kingman_Island "Kingman Island"), in the [Anacostia River](/wiki/Anacostia_River "Anacostia River"), is home to [Langston Golf Course](/wiki/Langston_Golf_Course "Langston Golf Course") and a public park with trails.^[\[253\]](#cite_note-260)^{#cite_ref-260}

[West Potomac Park](/wiki/West_Potomac_Park "West Potomac Park") includes the parkland that extends south of the [Lincoln Memorial Reflecting Pool](/wiki/Lincoln_Memorial_Reflecting_Pool "Lincoln Memorial Reflecting Pool"), from the [Lincoln Memorial](/wiki/Lincoln_Memorial "Lincoln Memorial") to the grounds of the [Washington Monument](/wiki/Washington_Monument "Washington Monument"). The park is the site of several national landmarks including the [Korean War Veterans Memorial](/wiki/Korean_War_Veterans_Memorial "Korean War Veterans Memorial"), [Jefferson Memorial](/wiki/Jefferson_Memorial "Jefferson Memorial"), [Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial](/wiki/Franklin_Delano_Roosevelt_Memorial "Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial"), [George Mason Memorial](/wiki/George_Mason_Memorial "George Mason Memorial"), and the [Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial](/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr._Memorial "Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial").^[\[254\]](#cite_note-261)^{#cite_ref-261}

Other parks, gardens, and squares include [Dumbarton Oaks](/wiki/Dumbarton_Oaks "Dumbarton Oaks"), [Meridian Hill Park](/wiki/Meridian_Hill_Park "Meridian Hill Park"), [the Yards](/wiki/The_Yards_(Washington,_D.C.) "The Yards (Washington, D.C.)"), [Anacostia Park](/wiki/Anacostia_Park "Anacostia Park"), [Lincoln Park](/wiki/Lincoln_Park_(Washington,_D.C.) "Lincoln Park (Washington, D.C.)"), [Kenilworth Park and Aquatic Gardens](/wiki/Kenilworth_Park_and_Aquatic_Gardens "Kenilworth Park and Aquatic Gardens"), [Franklin Square](/wiki/Franklin_Square_(Washington,_D.C.) "Franklin Square (Washington, D.C.)"), [McPherson Square](/wiki/McPherson_Square "McPherson Square"), [Farragut Square](/wiki/Farragut_Square "Farragut Square"), and [Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park](/wiki/Chesapeake_and_Ohio_Canal_National_Historical_Park "Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park").^[\[255\]](#cite_note-262)^ There are a large number of [traffic circles and circle parks in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/List_of_circles_in_Washington,_D.C. "List of circles in Washington, D.C."), including [Dupont Circle](/wiki/Dupont_Circle "Dupont Circle"), [Logan Circle](/wiki/Logan_Circle_(Washington,_D.C.) "Logan Circle (Washington, D.C.)"), [Scott Circle](/wiki/Scott_Circle "Scott Circle"), [Sheridan Circle](/wiki/Sheridan_Circle "Sheridan Circle"), [Thomas Circle](/wiki/Thomas_Circle "Thomas Circle"), [Washington Circle](/wiki/Washington_Circle "Washington Circle"), and others.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-262}

The [United States National Arboretum](/wiki/United_States_National_Arboretum "United States National Arboretum") is a dense [arboretum](/wiki/Arboretum "Arboretum") in Northeast D.C. filled with gardens and trails. Its most notable landmark is the [National Capitol Columns](/wiki/National_Capitol_Columns "National Capitol Columns") monument.^[\[256\]](#cite_note-263)^{#cite_ref-263}  

Sports {#Sports}
----------------

Main article: [Sports in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Sports_in_Washington,_D.C. "Sports in Washington, D.C.")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Pittsburgh_Penguins%2C_Washington_Capitals%2C_Bryan_Rust_%2833744033514%29.jpg/220px-Pittsburgh_Penguins%2C_Washington_Capitals%2C_Bryan_Rust_%2833744033514%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pittsburgh_Penguins,_Washington_Capitals,_Bryan_Rust_(33744033514).jpg) [Capital One Arena](/wiki/Capital_One_Arena "Capital One Arena") in the city's [Chinatown](/wiki/Chinatown,_Washington,_D.C. "Chinatown, Washington, D.C.") section hosts the [Washington Capitals](/wiki/Washington_Capitals "Washington Capitals"), an [NHL](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League") team (pictured), and the [Washington Wizards](/wiki/Washington_Wizards "Washington Wizards"), an [NBA](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball Association") team [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/2014_Marine_Corps_Marathon_in_front_of_US_Botoanic_Garden.jpg/220px-2014_Marine_Corps_Marathon_in_front_of_US_Botoanic_Garden.jpg)](/wiki/File:2014_Marine_Corps_Marathon_in_front_of_US_Botoanic_Garden.jpg) With over 30,000 participants as of 2024, the annual [Marine Corps Marathon](/wiki/Marine_Corps_Marathon "Marine Corps Marathon"), held annually in October in Washington, D.C. and [Arlington County](/wiki/Arlington_County,_Virginia "Arlington County, Virginia"), is the largest non-prize money marathon in the country.^[\[257\]](#cite_note-264)^

Washington, D.C. is one of 13 cities in the United States with teams from the [primary four major professional men's sports](/wiki/U.S._cities_with_teams_from_four_major_sports "U.S. cities with teams from four major sports") and is home to two major professional women's teams.^[\[258\]](#cite_note-265)^ The [Washington Nationals](/wiki/Washington_Nationals "Washington Nationals") of [Major League Baseball](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League Baseball") are the most popular sports team in the District, as of 2019.^[\[259\]](#cite_note-266)^ They play at [Nationals Park](/wiki/Nationals_Park "Nationals Park"), which opened in 2008. The [Washington Commanders](/wiki/Washington_Commanders "Washington Commanders") of the [National Football League](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League") play at [Northwest Stadium](/wiki/Northwest_Stadium "Northwest Stadium") in nearby [Landover, Maryland](/wiki/Landover,_Maryland "Landover, Maryland"). The [Washington Wizards](/wiki/Washington_Wizards "Washington Wizards") of the [National Basketball Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball Association") and the [Washington Capitals](/wiki/Washington_Capitals "Washington Capitals") of the [National Hockey League](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League") play at [Capital One Arena](/wiki/Capital_One_Arena "Capital One Arena") in the city's [Penn Quarter](/wiki/Penn_Quarter "Penn Quarter") neighborhood. The [Washington Mystics](/wiki/Washington_Mystics "Washington Mystics") of the [Women's National Basketball Association](/wiki/Women%27s_National_Basketball_Association "Women's National Basketball Association") play at [CareFirst Arena](/wiki/CareFirst_Arena "CareFirst Arena"). [D.C. United](/wiki/D.C._United "D.C. United") of [Major League Soccer](/wiki/Major_League_Soccer "Major League Soccer") and the [Washington Spirit](/wiki/Washington_Spirit "Washington Spirit") of the [National Women's Soccer League](/wiki/National_Women%27s_Soccer_League "National Women's Soccer League") play at [Audi Field](/wiki/Audi_Field "Audi Field").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-266}

The city's teams have won a combined 14 professional league championships over their respective histories. The Washington Commanders (named the Washington Redskins until 2020), have won two NFL Championships and three [Super Bowls](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl");^[\[260\]](#cite_note-267)^ D.C. United has won four;^[\[261\]](#cite_note-268)^ and the Washington Wizards, then named the Washington Bullets, Washington Capitals, Washington Mystics, Washington Nationals, and Washington Spirit have each won a single championship.^[\[262\]](#cite_note-269)^^[\[263\]](#cite_note-270)^{#cite_ref-270}

Other professional and semi-professional teams in Washington, D.C. include [DC Defenders](/wiki/DC_Defenders "DC Defenders") of the [XFL](/wiki/XFL_(2020) "XFL (2020)"), [Old Glory DC](/wiki/Old_Glory_DC "Old Glory DC") of [Major League Rugby](/wiki/Major_League_Rugby "Major League Rugby"), the [Washington Kastles](/wiki/Washington_Kastles "Washington Kastles") of World TeamTennis, and the [D.C. Divas](/wiki/D.C._Divas "D.C. Divas") of the Independent Women's Football League. The [William H.G. FitzGerald Tennis Center](/wiki/William_H.G._FitzGerald_Tennis_Center "William H.G. FitzGerald Tennis Center") in [Rock Creek Park](/wiki/Rock_Creek_Park "Rock Creek Park") hosts the [Washington Open](/wiki/Washington_Open_(tennis) "Washington Open (tennis)"), a joint men's [ATP Tour](/wiki/ATP_Tour "ATP Tour") [500](/wiki/ATP_500 "ATP 500")- and women's [WTA Tour](/wiki/WTA_Tour "WTA Tour") [500](/wiki/WTA_500 "WTA 500")-level tennis tournament, every summer in late July and early August. Washington, D.C. has two major annual marathon races, the [Marine Corps Marathon](/wiki/Marine_Corps_Marathon "Marine Corps Marathon"), held every autumn, and the [Rock 'n' Roll USA Marathon](/wiki/Rock_%27n%27_Roll_USA_Marathon "Rock 'n' Roll USA Marathon"), held each spring. The Marine Corps Marathon began in 1976 and is sometimes called "The People's Marathon" because it is the largest marathon that does not offer prize money to participants.^[\[264\]](#cite_note-271)^{#cite_ref-271}

The district's four [NCAA](/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association "National Collegiate Athletic Association") [Division I](/wiki/Division_I_(NCAA) "Division I (NCAA)") teams are the [American Eagles](/wiki/American_Eagles "American Eagles") of [American University](/wiki/American_University "American University"), [George Washington Revolutionaries](/wiki/George_Washington_Revolutionaries "George Washington Revolutionaries") of [George Washington University](/wiki/George_Washington_University "George Washington University"), the [Georgetown Hoyas](/wiki/Georgetown_Hoyas "Georgetown Hoyas") of [Georgetown University](/wiki/Georgetown_University "Georgetown University"), and the [Howard Bison and Lady Bison](/wiki/Howard_Bison_and_Lady_Bison "Howard Bison and Lady Bison") of [Howard University](/wiki/Howard_University "Howard University"). The [Georgetown men's basketball team](/wiki/Georgetown_Hoyas_men%27s_basketball "Georgetown Hoyas men's basketball") is the most notable and also plays at Capital One Arena. Washington, D.C. area's regional sports television network is [Monumental Sports Network](/wiki/Monumental_Sports_Network "Monumental Sports Network"), and was known as *NBC Sports Washington* until September 2023.^[\[265\]](#cite_note-272)^{#cite_ref-272}  

City government {#City_government}
----------------------------------

Main article: [Government of the District of Columbia](/wiki/Government_of_the_District_of_Columbia "Government of the District of Columbia")  

### Politics {#Politics}

Main article: [Elections in the District of Columbia](/wiki/Elections_in_the_District_of_Columbia "Elections in the District of Columbia")  
See also: [District of Columbia home rule](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_home_rule "District of Columbia home rule") and [List of District of Columbia symbols](/wiki/List_of_District_of_Columbia_symbols "List of District of Columbia symbols")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/John_A._Wilson_Building_west_side.jpg/220px-John_A._Wilson_Building_west_side.jpg)](/wiki/File:John_A._Wilson_Building_west_side.jpg) The [John A. Wilson Building](/wiki/John_A._Wilson_Building "John A. Wilson Building") on [Pennsylvania Avenue](/wiki/Pennsylvania_Avenue "Pennsylvania Avenue"), headquarters for much of the [Government of the District of Columbia](/wiki/Government_of_the_District_of_Columbia "Government of the District of Columbia"), including the offices of the [mayor](/wiki/Mayor_of_the_District_of_Columbia "Mayor of the District of Columbia") and [D.C. Council](/wiki/Council_of_the_District_of_Columbia "Council of the District of Columbia")

[Article One, Section Eight of the United States Constitution](/wiki/Article_One_of_the_United_States_Constitution "Article One of the United States Constitution") grants the [United States Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") "exclusive jurisdiction" over the city. The district did not have an elected local government until the passage of the [1973 Home Rule Act](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_Home_Rule_Act "District of Columbia Home Rule Act"). The Act devolved certain Congressional powers to an [elected mayor](/wiki/Mayor_of_the_District_of_Columbia "Mayor of the District of Columbia") and the thirteen-member [Council of the District of Columbia](/wiki/Council_of_the_District_of_Columbia "Council of the District of Columbia"). However, Congress retains the right to review and overturn laws created by the council and intervene in local affairs.^[\[266\]](#cite_note-273)^ Washington, D.C., is [overwhelmingly Democratic](/wiki/Political_party_strength_in_the_District_of_Columbia "Political party strength in the District of Columbia"), [having voted](/wiki/United_States_presidential_elections_in_the_District_of_Columbia "United States presidential elections in the District of Columbia") for the Democratic presidential candidate solidly since it was granted electoral votes [in 1964](/wiki/1964_United_States_presidential_election "1964 United States presidential election").^[\[267\]](#cite_note-274)^{#cite_ref-274}

Each of the city's eight [wards](/wiki/Ward_(country_subdivision) "Ward (country subdivision)") elects a single member of the council and residents elect four at-large members to represent the district as a whole. The council chair is also elected at-large.^[\[268\]](#cite_note-275)^ There are 37 [Advisory Neighborhood Commissions](/wiki/Advisory_Neighborhood_Commission "Advisory Neighborhood Commission") (ANCs) elected by small neighborhood districts. ANCs can issue recommendations on all issues that affect residents; government agencies take their advice under careful consideration.^[\[269\]](#cite_note-276)^ The [attorney general of the District of Columbia](/wiki/Attorney_General_of_the_District_of_Columbia "Attorney General of the District of Columbia") is elected to a four-year term.^[\[270\]](#cite_note-277)^{#cite_ref-277}

Washington, D.C., observes all [federal holidays](/wiki/Federal_holidays_in_the_United_States "Federal holidays in the United States") and also celebrates [Emancipation Day](/wiki/Emancipation_Day "Emancipation Day") on April 16, which commemorates the end of slavery in the district.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-emancipation-45)^ The [flag of Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Flag_of_Washington,_D.C. "Flag of Washington, D.C."), was adopted in 1938 and is a variation on George Washington's family [coat of arms](/wiki/Coat_of_arms "Coat of arms").^[\[271\]](#cite_note-278)^{#cite_ref-278}

Washington, D.C., has been a member state of the [Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization](/wiki/Unrepresented_Nations_and_Peoples_Organization "Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization") (UNPO) since 2015.^[\[272\]](#cite_note-279)^{#cite_ref-279}

The idiom "[Inside the Beltway](/wiki/Inside_the_Beltway "Inside the Beltway")" is a reference used by media to describe discussions of national political issues inside of Washington, by way of geographical demarcation regarding the region within the Capital's Beltway, Interstate 495, the city's highway loop (beltway) constructed in 1964. The phrase is used as a title for a number of political columns and news items by publications like *[The Washington Times](/wiki/The_Washington_Times "The Washington Times")* .^[\[273\]](#cite_note-280)^{#cite_ref-280}  

### Budgetary issues {#Budgetary_issues}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Muriel_Bowser_official_photo.jpg/220px-Muriel_Bowser_official_photo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Muriel_Bowser_official_photo.jpg) [Muriel Bowser](/wiki/Muriel_Bowser "Muriel Bowser"), the city's mayor since 2015

The mayor and council set local taxes and a budget, which Congress must approve. The [Government Accountability Office](/wiki/Government_Accountability_Office "Government Accountability Office") and other analysts have estimated that the city's high percentage of tax-exempt property and the Congressional prohibition of commuter taxes create a structural deficit in the district's local budget of anywhere between $470 million and over $1 billion per year. Congress typically provides additional grants for federal programs such as [Medicaid](/wiki/Medicaid "Medicaid") and the operation of the [local justice system](/wiki/National_Capital_Revitalization_and_Self-Government_Improvement_Act_of_1997 "National Capital Revitalization and Self-Government Improvement Act of 1997"); however, analysts claim that the payments do not fully resolve the imbalance.^[\[274\]](#cite_note-DCAppleseed-281)^^[\[275\]](#cite_note-GAO-282)^{#cite_ref-GAO_282-0}

The city's local government, particularly during the mayoralty of [Marion Barry](/wiki/Marion_Barry "Marion Barry"), has been criticized for mismanagement and waste.^[\[276\]](#cite_note-283)^ During his administration in 1989, *[Washington Monthly](/wiki/Washington_Monthly "Washington Monthly")* magazine labeled the district "the worst city government in America".^[\[277\]](#cite_note-284)^ In 1995, at the start of Barry's fourth term, Congress created the [District of Columbia Financial Control Board](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_Financial_Control_Board "District of Columbia Financial Control Board") to oversee all municipal spending.^[\[278\]](#cite_note-285)^ Mayor [Anthony Williams](/wiki/Anthony_A._Williams "Anthony A. Williams") won election in 1998 and oversaw a period of [urban renewal](/wiki/Urban_renewal "Urban renewal") and budget surpluses.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-285}

The district regained control over its finances in 2001 and the oversight board's operations were suspended.^[\[279\]](#cite_note-286)^{#cite_ref-286}

The district has a federally funded "Emergency Planning and Security Fund" to cover security related to visits by foreign leaders and diplomats, presidential inaugurations, protests, and terrorism concerns. During the Trump administration, the fund has run with a deficit. Trump's January 2017 inauguration cost the city $27 million; of that, $7 million was never repaid to the fund. Trump's 2019 Independence Day event, "A Salute to America", cost six times more than Independence Day events in past years.^[\[280\]](#cite_note-287)^{#cite_ref-287}  

### Homelessness {#Homelessness}

The city passed a law that requires shelter to be provided to everyone in need when the temperature drops below freezing.^[\[281\]](#cite_note-288)^ Since D.C. does not have enough shelter units available, every winter it books hotel rooms in the suburbs with an average cost of around $100 for a night. According to the D.C. Department of Human Services, during the winter of 2012 the city spent $2,544,454 on putting homeless families in hotels,^[\[282\]](#cite_note-289)^ and budgeted $3.2 million on hotel beds in 2013.^[\[283\]](#cite_note-290)^{#cite_ref-290}  

Federal voting rights {#Federal_voting_rights}
----------------------------------------------

See also: [District of Columbia voting rights](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_voting_rights "District of Columbia voting rights"); [Political party strength in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Political_party_strength_in_Washington,_D.C. "Political party strength in Washington, D.C."); and [District of Columbia federal voting rights](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_federal_voting_rights "District of Columbia federal voting rights")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Washington%2C_D.C._license_plate%2C_2017.png/220px-Washington%2C_D.C._license_plate%2C_2017.png)](/wiki/File:Washington,_D.C._license_plate,_2017.png) The city's [license plate](/wiki/Vehicle_registration_plates_of_Washington,_D.C. "Vehicle registration plates of Washington, D.C."), which calls for an end to [taxation without representation](/wiki/No_taxation_without_representation "No taxation without representation") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/WashMonument_WhiteHouse.jpg/220px-WashMonument_WhiteHouse.jpg)](/wiki/File:WashMonument_WhiteHouse.jpg) The [Washington Monument](/wiki/Washington_Monument "Washington Monument") (forefront) and [White House](/wiki/White_House "White House") (center) in September 2003. Since 1961, the city's residents can vote for the [U.S. president](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States") and [vice president](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of the United States"), who also serves as [President of the Senate](/wiki/President_of_the_Senate "President of the Senate"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Abraham_Lincoln_v2.jpg/220px-Abraham_Lincoln_v2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_v2.jpg) The *[Abraham Lincoln Statue](/wiki/Statue_of_Abraham_Lincoln_(Lincoln_Memorial) "Statue of Abraham Lincoln (Lincoln Memorial)")* at the [Lincoln Memorial](/wiki/Lincoln_Memorial "Lincoln Memorial") in September 2016

Congress controlled the Federal District from its establishment, and did not make a provision for federal representation of the people living there. That changed in 1961, when the 23rd amendment was ratified by the states, and Washington, D.C. was granted three electoral college votes in each presidential election. In 1978 another amendment was passed but not ratified by the states to grant D.C. congressional representation. In 2021, a bill to make D.C. a state passed the House of Representatives but not Senate. Congress has the power to add a state, but an amendment must be ratified by the states.

Washington, D.C. is not a state and therefore has no federal voting representation in [Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress"). The city's residents elect a [non-voting delegate](/wiki/Non-voting_members_of_the_United_States_House_of_representatives "Non-voting members of the United States House of representatives") to the [House of Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States House of Representatives") ([D.C. at-large](/wiki/District_of_Columbia%27s_at-large_congressional_district "District of Columbia's at-large congressional district")), who may sit on committees, participate in debate, and introduce legislation, but cannot vote on the [House floor](/wiki/Floor_(legislative) "Floor (legislative)"). The district has no official representation in the [United States Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate"). Neither chamber seats the district's elected ["shadow" representative or senators](/wiki/Shadow_congressperson "Shadow congressperson"). Unlike residents of [U.S. territories](/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States "Territories of the United States") such as [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico") or [Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam"), which also have non-voting delegates, D.C. residents are subject to all federal taxes.^[\[284\]](#cite_note-291)^ In the financial year 2012, D.C. residents and businesses paid $20.7 billion in federal taxes, more than the taxes collected from 19 states and the highest [federal taxes per capita](/wiki/Federal_tax_revenue_by_state "Federal tax revenue by state").^[\[285\]](#cite_note-292)^{#cite_ref-292}

A 2005 poll found that 78% of Americans did not know residents of Washington, D.C., have less representation in Congress than residents of the 50 states.^[\[286\]](#cite_note-votepoll-293)^ Efforts to raise awareness about the issue have included campaigns by [grassroots](/wiki/Grassroots "Grassroots") organizations and featuring the city's unofficial motto, "[End Taxation Without Representation](/wiki/No_taxation_without_representation "No taxation without representation")", on [D.C. vehicle license plates](/wiki/Vehicle_registration_plates_of_Washington,_D.C. "Vehicle registration plates of Washington, D.C.").^[\[287\]](#cite_note-294)^ There is evidence of nationwide approval for D.C. voting rights; various polls indicate that 61 to 82% of Americans believe D.C. should have voting representation in Congress.^[\[286\]](#cite_note-votepoll-293)^^[\[288\]](#cite_note-295)^{#cite_ref-295}

Opponents to federal voting rights for Washington, D.C., propose that the [Founding Fathers](/wiki/Founding_Fathers_of_the_United_States "Founding Fathers of the United States") never intended for district residents to have a vote in Congress since the Constitution makes clear that representation must come from the states. Those opposed to making the District of Columbia a state say such a move would destroy the notion of a separate national capital and that statehood would unfairly grant Senate representation to a single city.^[\[289\]](#cite_note-296)^{#cite_ref-296}

The District was granted presidential voting rights by the 23rd Amendment in 1961.^[\[290\]](#cite_note-297)^ The [23rd Amendment](/wiki/Twenty-third_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Twenty-third Amendment to the United States Constitution") was ratified which granted the people of the Washington, D.C., the right to vote for the president. This was done by giving them electoral college votes they would get if they were a state, but it must be no more than the least a state has; this works out to three electoral college votes. The amendment reads, ".. A number of electors of President and Vice President equal to the whole number of Senators and Representatives in Congress to which the District would be entitled if it were a State, but in no event more than the least populous State".^[\[291\]](#cite_note-298)^ The 23rd Amendment could complicate statehood, because it would apply even if the federal district was shrunk, and undoing the amendment requires another amendment.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-sthd101-63)^ Congress must operate from a district it controls, but it can be no larger than ten miles on a side; the 2021 statehood bill got around this by proposing the federal district be shrunk to an area roughly the size of the national mall.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-sthd101-63)^{#cite_ref-sthd101_63-2}

In 2021, Senator [Joe Manchin](/wiki/Joe_Manchin "Joe Manchin") made known his non-support of the [D.C. Statehood bill](/wiki/DC_Admission_Act "DC Admission Act") that had passed the House of Representatives, and suggested that D.C. could instead be given statehood by constitutional amendment.^[\[292\]](#cite_note-din-299)^ He was concerned about complications from the 23rd amendment and said the bill would likely end up in court, adding that the correct way was to propose a constitutional amendment and let the nation vote on it.^[\[292\]](#cite_note-din-299)^{#cite_ref-din_299-1}

In 1978, the [District of Columbia Voting Rights Amendment](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_Voting_Rights_Amendment "District of Columbia Voting Rights Amendment") was passed, which would have granted D.C. Congressional representation, but it expired in 1986 without being ratified into law.^[\[293\]](#cite_note-300)^{#cite_ref-300}

In 2021, a bill was introduced to congress for [retroceding the district](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_retrocession "District of Columbia retrocession") to Maryland.^[\[294\]](#cite_note-301)^ The idea was that by returning the area to Maryland, the residents would have normal State representation.^[\[295\]](#cite_note-302)^{#cite_ref-302}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

See also: [District of Columbia Public Schools](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_Public_Schools "District of Columbia Public Schools") and [List of parochial and private schools in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/List_of_parochial_and_private_schools_in_Washington,_D.C. "List of parochial and private schools in Washington, D.C.")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Duke_Ellington_School_of_the_Arts%2C_Georgetown%2C_Washington%2C_DC_%2839642750063%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Duke_Ellington_School_of_the_Arts%2C_Georgetown%2C_Washington%2C_DC_%2839642750063%29_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Duke_Ellington_School_of_the_Arts,_Georgetown,_Washington,_DC_(39642750063)_(cropped).jpg) [Duke Ellington School of the Arts](/wiki/Duke_Ellington_School_of_the_Arts "Duke Ellington School of the Arts"), a public [magnet school](/wiki/Magnet_school "Magnet school") in the city

[District of Columbia Public Schools](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_Public_Schools "District of Columbia Public Schools") (DCPS), the sole public school district in the city,^[\[296\]](#cite_note-303)^ operates the city's 123 public schools.^[\[297\]](#cite_note-dcps-304)^ The number of students in DCPS steadily decreased for 39 years until 2009. In the 2010--11 school year, 46,191 students were enrolled in the public school system.^[\[298\]](#cite_note-DCenroll-305)^ DCPS has one of the highest-cost, yet lowest-performing school systems in the country, in terms of both infrastructure and student achievement.^[\[299\]](#cite_note-306)^ Mayor Adrian Fenty's administration made sweeping changes to the system by closing schools, replacing teachers, firing principals, and using private education firms to aid curriculum development.^[\[300\]](#cite_note-307)^{#cite_ref-307}

The [District of Columbia Public Charter School Board](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_Public_Charter_School_Board "District of Columbia Public Charter School Board") monitors the 52 public charter schools in the city.^[\[301\]](#cite_note-308)^ Due to the perceived problems with the traditional public school system, enrollment in public [charter schools](/wiki/Charter_school "Charter school") had by 2007 steadily increased.^[\[302\]](#cite_note-309)^ As of 2010, D.C., charter schools had a total enrollment of about 32,000, a 9% increase from the prior year.^[\[298\]](#cite_note-DCenroll-305)^ The district is also home to 92 private schools, which enrolled approximately 18,000 students in 2008.^[\[303\]](#cite_note-310)^{#cite_ref-310}  

### Higher education {#Higher_education}

See also: [List of colleges and universities in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/List_of_colleges_and_universities_in_Washington,_D.C. "List of colleges and universities in Washington, D.C.")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Healy_Hall_Georgetown_University.jpg/220px-Healy_Hall_Georgetown_University.jpg)](/wiki/File:Healy_Hall_Georgetown_University.jpg) [Georgetown University](/wiki/Georgetown_University "Georgetown University"), founded in 1789, the city's oldest university

The [University of the District of Columbia](/wiki/University_of_the_District_of_Columbia "University of the District of Columbia") (UDC) is a public [land-grant university](/wiki/Land-grant_university "Land-grant university") providing undergraduate and graduate education.^[\[304\]](#cite_note-311)^ [Federally chartered universities](/wiki/University_charter#Federal "University charter") include [American University](/wiki/American_University "American University") (AU), [Gallaudet University](/wiki/Gallaudet_University "Gallaudet University"), [George Washington University](/wiki/George_Washington_University "George Washington University") (GWU), [Georgetown University](/wiki/Georgetown_University "Georgetown University") (GU), and [Howard University](/wiki/Howard_University "Howard University") (HU). Other private universities include the [Catholic University of America](/wiki/Catholic_University_of_America "Catholic University of America") (CUA), the [Johns Hopkins University](/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_University "Johns Hopkins University") [Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies](/wiki/Paul_H._Nitze_School_of_Advanced_International_Studies "Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies") (SAIS), and [Trinity Washington University](/wiki/Trinity_Washington_University "Trinity Washington University"). The [Corcoran College of Art and Design](/wiki/Corcoran_College_of_Art_and_Design "Corcoran College of Art and Design"), the oldest art school in the capital, was absorbed into the George Washington University in 2014, now serving as its college of arts.^[\[305\]](#cite_note-312)^{#cite_ref-312}

The city's medical research institutions include [Washington Hospital Center](/wiki/Washington_Hospital_Center "Washington Hospital Center") and [Children's National Medical Center](/wiki/Children%27s_National_Medical_Center "Children's National Medical Center"). The city is home to three medical schools and associated teaching hospitals: George Washington, Georgetown, and Howard universities.^[\[306\]](#cite_note-313)^{#cite_ref-313}  

### Libraries {#Libraries}

Washington, D.C., has dozens of public and private libraries and [library systems](/wiki/Library_system "Library system"), including the [District of Columbia Public Library](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_Public_Library "District of Columbia Public Library") [system](/wiki/Library_system "Library system").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ [Folger Shakespeare Library](/wiki/Folger_Shakespeare_Library "Folger Shakespeare Library"), a research library and museum located in the [Capitol Hill](/wiki/Capitol_Hill "Capitol Hill") neighborhood, houses the world's largest collection of material related to [William Shakespeare](/wiki/William_Shakespeare "William Shakespeare").^[\[307\]](#cite_note-314)^{#cite_ref-314}  

#### Library of Congress {#Library_of_Congress}

Main article: [Library of Congress](/wiki/Library_of_Congress "Library of Congress")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/LOC_Main_Reading_Room_Highsmith.jpg/220px-LOC_Main_Reading_Room_Highsmith.jpg)](/wiki/File:LOC_Main_Reading_Room_Highsmith.jpg) The [Library of Congress](/wiki/Library_of_Congress "Library of Congress"), the [world's largest library](/wiki/List_of_largest_libraries "List of largest libraries") with more than 173 million items^[\[h\]](#cite_note-316)^

The [Library of Congress](/wiki/Library_of_Congress "Library of Congress") is the [research](/wiki/Research_library "Research library") [library](/wiki/Library "Library") that officially serves the [United States Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") and is the *[de facto](/wiki/De_facto "De facto")* [national library](/wiki/National_library "National library") of the United States. It is a complex of three buildings: [Thomas Jefferson Building](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson_Building "Thomas Jefferson Building"), [John Adams Building](/wiki/John_Adams_Building "John Adams Building") and [James Madison Memorial Building](/wiki/James_Madison_Memorial_Building "James Madison Memorial Building"), all located in the [Capitol Hill](/wiki/Capitol_Hill "Capitol Hill") neighborhood. The Jefferson Building houses the library's reading room, a copy of the [Gutenberg Bible](/wiki/Gutenberg_Bible "Gutenberg Bible"), [Thomas Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson")'s original library, and several museum exhibits.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^  

#### District of Columbia Public Library {#District_of_Columbia_Public_Library}

Main article: [District of Columbia Public Library](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_Public_Library "District of Columbia Public Library")

The [District of Columbia Public Library](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_Public_Library "District of Columbia Public Library") operates 26 neighborhood locations including the landmark [Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Library](/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr._Memorial_Library "Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Library").^[\[309\]](#cite_note-317)^{#cite_ref-317}  

Media {#Media}
--------------

"List of newspapers in Washington, D.C."); [List of films set in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/List_of_films_set_in_Washington,_D.C.
