"List of television shows set in Washington, D.C.")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Franklin_Park_%26_One_Franklin_Square_-_Washington%2C_D.C..jpg/220px-Franklin_Park_%26_One_Franklin_Square_-_Washington%2C_D.C..jpg)](/wiki/File:Franklin_Park_%26_One_Franklin_Square_-_Washington,_D.C..jpg) [One Franklin Square](/wiki/One_Franklin_Square "One Franklin Square") in [Downtown](/wiki/Downtown_(Washington,_D.C.) "Downtown (Washington, D.C.)") houses the headquarters of *[The Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post")* , the [nation's third-largest newspaper by circulation](/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_the_United_States "List of newspapers in the United States") as of 2023

Washington, D.C., is a prominent center for national and international media. *[The Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post")* , founded in 1877, is the city's most-read local daily newspaper^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ and one of the preeminent newspapers in the United States.^[\[310\]](#cite_note-318)^ It had the sixth-highest readership of all news dailies in the country in 2011.^[\[311\]](#cite_note-319)^ The *Post* previously also published the [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language")-language newspaper *[El Tiempo Latino](/wiki/El_Tiempo_Latino "El Tiempo Latino")* , which it sold to [El Planeta Media](/wiki/El_Planeta_Media "El Planeta Media") in 2016.^[\[312\]](#cite_note-320)^{#cite_ref-320}

*[The Washington Times](/wiki/The_Washington_Times "The Washington Times")* is a general interest daily newspaper and popular among [conservatives](/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States "Conservatism in the United States").^[\[313\]](#cite_note-321)^ The [alternative weekly](/wiki/Alternative_newspaper "Alternative newspaper") *[Washington City Paper](/wiki/Washington_City_Paper "Washington City Paper")* , with a circulation of 47,000, is also based in the city and has a substantial readership in the Washington area.^[\[314\]](#cite_note-322)^^[\[315\]](#cite_note-323)^{#cite_ref-323}

*[The Atlantic](/wiki/The_Atlantic "The Atlantic")* magazine, which has covered politics, international affairs, and cultural issues since 1857, was previously headquartered at the [Watergate complex](/wiki/Watergate_complex "Watergate complex") but is now headquartered in a building at [the Wharf](/wiki/The_Wharf_(Washington,_D.C.) "The Wharf (Washington, D.C.)") in Washington.^[\[316\]](#cite_note-324)^{#cite_ref-324}

Several community and specialty papers focus on neighborhood and cultural issues, including the weekly *[Washington Blade](/wiki/Washington_Blade "Washington Blade")* and *[Metro Weekly](/wiki/Metro_Weekly "Metro Weekly")* , which focus on LGBT issues; the *[Washington Informer](/wiki/Washington_Informer "Washington Informer")* and *[The Washington Afro American](/wiki/The_Washington_Afro_American "The Washington Afro American")* , which highlight topics of interest to the black community; and neighborhood newspapers published by [The Current Newspapers](/wiki/The_Current_Newspapers "The Current Newspapers"). *[Congressional Quarterly](/wiki/Congressional_Quarterly "Congressional Quarterly")* , *[The Hill](/wiki/The_Hill_(newspaper) "The Hill (newspaper)")* , *[Politico](/wiki/Politico_(newspaper) "Politico (newspaper)")* , and *[Roll Call](/wiki/Roll_Call "Roll Call")* newspapers focus exclusively on issues related to Congress and the federal government. Other publications based in Washington include the *[National Geographic](/wiki/National_Geographic_(magazine) "National Geographic (magazine)")* magazine and political publications such as *[The Washington Examiner](/wiki/The_Washington_Examiner "The Washington Examiner")* , *[The New Republic](/wiki/The_New_Republic "The New Republic")* , and *[Washington Monthly](/wiki/Washington_Monthly "Washington Monthly")* .^[\[317\]](#cite_note-325)^ *[USA Today](/wiki/USA_Today "USA Today")* , which is the [largest newspaper in the country as measured by circulation](/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_the_United_States "List of newspapers in the United States"), is headquartered in nearby [Tysons, Virginia](/wiki/Tysons,_Virginia "Tysons, Virginia").^[\[318\]](#cite_note-326)^^[\[319\]](#cite_note-327)^{#cite_ref-327}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/BB_DC_set_election_11.16.jpg/220px-BB_DC_set_election_11.16.jpg)](/wiki/File:BB_DC_set_election_11.16.jpg) [CNN](/wiki/CNN "CNN") reporting from the city during the [2016 U.S. presidential election](/wiki/2016_United_States_presidential_election "2016 United States presidential election")

The [Washington metropolitan area](/wiki/Washington_metropolitan_area "Washington metropolitan area") is the ninth-largest television media market in the nation, with two million homes, representing approximately 2% of the country's television market.^[\[320\]](#cite_note-328)^ Several media companies and cable television channels have their headquarters in the area, including [C-SPAN](/wiki/C-SPAN "C-SPAN"), [Radio One](/wiki/Radio_One_(company) "Radio One (company)"), the [National Geographic Channel](/wiki/National_Geographic_Channel "National Geographic Channel"), [Smithsonian Networks](/wiki/Smithsonian_Networks "Smithsonian Networks"), [National Public Radio](/wiki/National_Public_Radio "National Public Radio") (NPR), [Travel Channel](/wiki/Travel_Channel "Travel Channel") (in [Chevy Chase, Maryland](/wiki/Chevy_Chase,_Maryland "Chevy Chase, Maryland")), [Discovery Communications](/wiki/Discovery_Channel "Discovery Channel") (in [Silver Spring, Maryland](/wiki/Silver_Spring,_Maryland "Silver Spring, Maryland")), and [PBS](/wiki/PBS "PBS") (in [Arlington County, Virginia](/wiki/Arlington_County,_Virginia "Arlington County, Virginia")). The headquarters of [Voice of America](/wiki/Voice_of_America "Voice of America"), the U.S. government's international news service, is near the Capitol in Southwest Washington, D.C.^[\[321\]](#cite_note-329)^{#cite_ref-329}

The city is served by two local NPR affiliates, [WAMU](/wiki/WAMU "WAMU") and [WETA](/wiki/WETA_(FM) "WETA (FM)").^[\[322\]](#cite_note-330)^{#cite_ref-330}  

Infrastructure {#Infrastructure}
--------------------------------

### Transportation {#Transportation}

Main article: [Transportation in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Transportation_in_Washington,_D.C. "Transportation in Washington, D.C.")  

#### Streets and highways {#Streets_and_highways}

Main article: [Streets and highways of Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Streets_and_highways_of_Washington,_D.C. "Streets and highways of Washington, D.C.")  
See also: [List of circles in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/List_of_circles_in_Washington,_D.C. "List of circles in Washington, D.C.")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/View_down_Pennsylvania_Avenue_NW_from_the_Old_Post_Office_Tower_-01-_%2812798494884%29.jpg/220px-View_down_Pennsylvania_Avenue_NW_from_the_Old_Post_Office_Tower_-01-_%2812798494884%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:View_down_Pennsylvania_Avenue_NW_from_the_Old_Post_Office_Tower_-01-_(12798494884).jpg) [Pennsylvania Avenue](/wiki/Pennsylvania_Avenue "Pennsylvania Avenue"), one of the city's most prominent streets, connects the [U.S. Capitol](/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol") and [White House](/wiki/White_House "White House").

There are 1,500 miles (2,400 km) of streets, parkways, and avenues in the district.^[\[323\]](#cite_note-331)^ Due to the [freeway revolts](/wiki/Highway_revolts_in_the_United_States "Highway revolts in the United States") of the 1960s, much of the proposed [interstate highway system](/wiki/Interstate_highway_system "Interstate highway system") through the middle of Washington was never built. [Interstate 95](/wiki/Interstate_95_in_the_District_of_Columbia "Interstate 95 in the District of Columbia") (I-95), the nation's major east coast highway, therefore bends around the district to form the eastern portion of the [Capital Beltway](/wiki/Interstate_495_(Capital_Beltway) "Interstate 495 (Capital Beltway)"). A portion of the proposed highway funding was directed to the region's public transportation infrastructure instead.^[\[324\]](#cite_note-332)^ The interstate highways that continue into Washington, including [I-66](/wiki/Interstate_66 "Interstate 66") and [I-395](/wiki/Interstate_395_(Virginia%E2%80%93District_of_Columbia) "Interstate 395 (Virginia–District of Columbia)"), both terminate shortly after entering the city.^[\[325\]](#cite_note-333)^{#cite_ref-333}

According to a 2010 study, Washington-area commuters spent 70 hours a year in traffic delays, which tied with Chicago for having the nation's worst road congestion.^[\[326\]](#cite_note-334)^ However, 37% of Washington-area commuters take public transportation to work, the second-highest rate in the country.^[\[327\]](#cite_note-335)^ An additional 12% of D.C. commuters walked to work, 6% carpooled, and 3% traveled by bicycle in 2010.^[\[328\]](#cite_note-336)^{#cite_ref-336}  

#### Cycling {#Cycling}

Further information: [Capital Bikeshare](/wiki/Capital_Bikeshare "Capital Bikeshare")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Capital_Bikeshare_DC_2010_10_545.JPG/220px-Capital_Bikeshare_DC_2010_10_545.JPG)](/wiki/File:Capital_Bikeshare_DC_2010_10_545.JPG) A [Capital Bikeshare](/wiki/Capital_Bikeshare "Capital Bikeshare") rental station near [McPherson Square](/wiki/McPherson_Square "McPherson Square")

In May 2022, the city celebrated the expansion of its [bike lane network](/wiki/Cycling_infrastructure "Cycling infrastructure") to 104 miles (167 km), a 60 percent increase from 2015. Of those miles, 24 miles (39 km) were [protected bike lanes](/wiki/Protected_bike_lane "Protected bike lane"). It also boasted 62 miles (100 km) of [bike trails](/wiki/Bike_trail "Bike trail").^[\[329\]](#cite_note-337)^ As of March 2023^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Washington,_D.C.&action=edit)^, the city has 108 miles (174 km) of bike lanes, with 30 miles (48 km) of them protected bike lanes.^[\[330\]](#cite_note-338)^{#cite_ref-338}

D.C. is part of the regional [Capital Bikeshare](/wiki/Capital_Bikeshare "Capital Bikeshare") program. Started in 2010, it is one of the largest [bicycle sharing systems](/wiki/Bicycle_sharing_system "Bicycle sharing system") in the country. As of February 2024^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Washington,_D.C.&action=edit)^, the program had 6,372 bicycles and 395 stations.^[\[331\]](#cite_note-339)^ A preceding [SmartBike DC](/wiki/SmartBike_DC "SmartBike DC") pilot program had begun in 2008.^[\[332\]](#cite_note-340)^{#cite_ref-340}  

#### Walkability {#Walkability}

A 2021 study by [Walk Score](/wiki/Walk_Score "Walk Score") ranked Washington, D.C. the fifth-most walkable city in the country. According to the study, the most walkable neighborhoods are [U Street](/wiki/U_Street_(Washington,_D.C.) "U Street (Washington, D.C.)"), [Dupont Circle](/wiki/Dupont_Circle "Dupont Circle"), and [Mount Vernon Square](/wiki/Mount_Vernon_Square "Mount Vernon Square").^[\[333\]](#cite_note-341)^ In 2013, the [Washington Metropolitan Area](/wiki/Washington_Metropolitan_Area "Washington Metropolitan Area") had the eighth lowest percentage of workers who commuted by private automobile (75.7 percent), with 8 percent of area workers traveling via rail transit.^[\[334\]](#cite_note-342)^{#cite_ref-342}  

#### River crossings {#River_crossings}

See also: [List of crossings of the Potomac River](/wiki/List_of_crossings_of_the_Potomac_River "List of crossings of the Potomac River") and [List of bridges on the National Register of Historic Places in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/List_of_bridges_on_the_National_Register_of_Historic_Places_in_Washington,_D.C. "List of bridges on the National Register of Historic Places in Washington, D.C.")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Memorial_Bridge_sunrise.jpg/220px-Memorial_Bridge_sunrise.jpg)](/wiki/File:Memorial_Bridge_sunrise.jpg) [Memorial Bridge](/wiki/Arlington_Memorial_Bridge "Arlington Memorial Bridge") connects the city across the [Potomac River](/wiki/Potomac_River "Potomac River") with [Arlington, Virginia](/wiki/Arlington_County,_Virginia "Arlington County, Virginia").

There are multiple transportation methods to cross the city's two rivers, the [Potomac River](/wiki/Potomac_River "Potomac River") and the [Anacostia River](/wiki/Anacostia_River "Anacostia River"). There are numerous bridges that take cars, trains, pedestrians, and bikers across the rivers. Among these are [Arlington Memorial Bridge](/wiki/Arlington_Memorial_Bridge "Arlington Memorial Bridge"), the [14th Street Bridges](/wiki/14th_Street_Bridges "14th Street Bridges"), [Francis Scott Key Bridge](/wiki/Francis_Scott_Key_Bridge_(Washington,_D.C.) "Francis Scott Key Bridge (Washington, D.C.)"), [Theodore Roosevelt Bridge](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt_Bridge "Theodore Roosevelt Bridge"), [Woodrow Wilson Bridge](/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson_Bridge "Woodrow Wilson Bridge"), and [Frederick Douglass Bridge](/wiki/Frederick_Douglass_Bridge "Frederick Douglass Bridge").^[\[335\]](#cite_note-343)^{#cite_ref-343}

There are also ferries and water cruises that cross the Potomac River. One of these is the Potomac Water Taxi, operated by [Hornblower Cruises](/wiki/Hornblower_Cruises "Hornblower Cruises"), which goes between the [Georgetown Waterfront](/wiki/Georgetown_Waterfront_Park "Georgetown Waterfront Park"), [the Wharf](/wiki/The_Wharf_(Washington,_D.C.) "The Wharf (Washington, D.C.)"), the [Old Town Alexandria](/wiki/Old_Town_Alexandria "Old Town Alexandria") Waterfront, and [National Harbor](/wiki/National_Harbor "National Harbor").^[\[336\]](#cite_note-344)^{#cite_ref-344}  

#### Rail {#Rail}

See also: [List of railroads in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/List_of_railroads_in_Washington,_D.C. "List of railroads in Washington, D.C.")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Farragut_West_DC_Metro_td_%282018-04-29%29_052.jpg/220px-Farragut_West_DC_Metro_td_%282018-04-29%29_052.jpg)](/wiki/File:Farragut_West_DC_Metro_td_(2018-04-29)_052.jpg) [Washington Metro](/wiki/Washington_Metro "Washington Metro"), the [second-busiest](/wiki/List_of_United_States_rapid_transit_systems_by_ridership "List of United States rapid transit systems by ridership") rapid rail system in the U.S. based on average weekday ridership, is known for its iconic vaulted ceilings

The [Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority](/wiki/Washington_Metropolitan_Area_Transit_Authority "Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority") (WMATA) operates the [Washington Metro](/wiki/Washington_Metro "Washington Metro"), the city's [rapid transit](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") rail system. The system serves Washington, D.C. and its [Maryland](/wiki/Maryland "Maryland") and [Northern Virginia](/wiki/Northern_Virginia "Northern Virginia") suburbs. Metro opened on March 27, 1976, and consists of six lines (each one color coded), [98 stations](/wiki/List_of_Washington_Metro_stations "List of Washington Metro stations"), and 129 miles (208 km) of track.^[\[337\]](#cite_note-345)^ Metro is the [second-busiest rapid transit system](/wiki/List_of_United_States_rapid_transit_systems_by_ridership "List of United States rapid transit systems by ridership") in the country and [fifth-busiest in North America](/wiki/List_of_North_American_rapid_transit_systems_by_ridership "List of North American rapid transit systems by ridership").^[\[338\]](#cite_note-346)^ It operates mostly as a deep-level [subway](/wiki/Passenger_rail_terminology#Subway "Passenger rail terminology") in more densely populated parts of the D.C. metropolitan area (including most of the District itself), while most of the suburban tracks are at surface level or [elevated](/wiki/Elevated_railway "Elevated railway"). Metro is known for its iconic [brutalist-style](/wiki/Brutalism "Brutalism") vaulted ceilings in the interior stations. It is also known for having long escalators in some of its underground stations. The longest single-tier escalator in the Western Hemisphere, spanning 230 feet (70 m), is located at Metro's [Wheaton station](/wiki/Wheaton_station_(Washington_Metro) "Wheaton station (Washington Metro)") in Maryland.^[\[339\]](#cite_note-facts_2017-347)^{#cite_ref-facts_2017_347-0}

[Washington Union Station](/wiki/Washington_Union_Station "Washington Union Station") is the city's main train station and serves approximately 70,000 people each day. It is [Amtrak](/wiki/Amtrak "Amtrak")'s second-busiest station with 4.6 million passengers annually and is the southern terminus for the [Northeast Corridor](/wiki/Northeast_Corridor "Northeast Corridor"), which carries long-distance and regional services to [New York Penn Station](/wiki/Pennsylvania_Station_(New_York_City) "Pennsylvania Station (New York City)") and points in New England. As of 2023, Union Station is the [ninth-busiest rail station](/wiki/List_of_busiest_railway_stations_in_North_America "List of busiest railway stations in North America") in the nation and tenth-busiest in [North America](/wiki/North_America "North America").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

Maryland's [MARC](/wiki/MARC_Train "MARC Train") and Virginia's [VRE](/wiki/Virginia_Railway_Express "Virginia Railway Express") commuter trains and the Metrorail [Red Line](/wiki/Red_Line_(Washington_Metro) "Red Line (Washington Metro)") also provide service into Union Station.^[\[340\]](#cite_note-348)^ Following renovations in 2011, Union Station became Washington's primary [intercity bus](/wiki/Intercity_bus "Intercity bus") transit center.^[\[341\]](#cite_note-349)^{#cite_ref-349}

Although Washington, D.C. was known throughout the 19th and early- to mid-20th centuries for [its streetcars](/wiki/Streetcars_in_Washington,_D.C. "Streetcars in Washington, D.C."), these lines were dismantled in the 1960s. In 2016, however, the city brought back a streetcar line, [DC Streetcar](/wiki/DC_Streetcar "DC Streetcar"), which is a single line system in Northeast Washington, D.C., along [H Street](/wiki/H_Street_(Washington,_D.C.) "H Street (Washington, D.C.)") and [Benning Road](/wiki/Benning_Road "Benning Road"), known as the [H Street/Benning Road Line](/wiki/H_Street/Benning_Road_Line "H Street/Benning Road Line").^[\[342\]](#cite_note-WAPO-350)^{#cite_ref-WAPO_350-0}  

#### Bus {#Bus}

Main article: [Metrobus (Washington, D.C.)](/wiki/Metrobus_(Washington,_D.C.) "Metrobus (Washington, D.C.)")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/WMATA_2015_New_Flyer_XDE60_5462.jpg/220px-WMATA_2015_New_Flyer_XDE60_5462.jpg)](/wiki/File:WMATA_2015_New_Flyer_XDE60_5462.jpg) [Metrobus](/wiki/Metrobus_(Washington,_D.C.) "Metrobus (Washington, D.C.)"), operated by the [Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority](/wiki/Washington_Metropolitan_Area_Transit_Authority "Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority")

Two main public bus systems operate in Washington, D.C. [Metrobus](/wiki/Metrobus_(Washington,_D.C.) "Metrobus (Washington, D.C.)"), operated by the [Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority](/wiki/Washington_Metropolitan_Area_Transit_Authority "Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority") (WMATA), is the primary public bus system in Washington, D.C. Serving more than 400,000 riders each weekday, it is one of the nation's [largest bus systems](/wiki/List_of_United_States_local_bus_agencies_by_ridership "List of United States local bus agencies by ridership") by annual ridership.^[\[343\]](#cite_note-351)^ The city also operates its own [DC Circulator](/wiki/DC_Circulator "DC Circulator") bus system, which connects commercial and touristic areas within central Washington.^[\[344\]](#cite_note-352)^ The DC Circulator costs only $1 to ride and is composed of six distinct routes that cover central D.C. and suburban [Rosslyn, Virginia](/wiki/Rosslyn,_Virginia "Rosslyn, Virginia"). The DC Circulator is run via a public-private partnership between the [District of Columbia Department of Transportation](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_Department_of_Transportation "District of Columbia Department of Transportation"), WMATA, and DC Surface Transit, Inc. (DCST). The bus system services each stop approximately every 10 minutes.^[\[345\]](#cite_note-353)^{#cite_ref-353}

Many other public bus systems operate in the various jurisdictions of the Washington region outside of the city in suburban Maryland and Virginia. Among these are the [Fairfax Connector](/wiki/Fairfax_Connector "Fairfax Connector") in [Fairfax County, Virginia](/wiki/Fairfax_County,_Virginia "Fairfax County, Virginia"); [DASH](/wiki/DASH_(bus) "DASH (bus)") in [Alexandria, Virginia](/wiki/Alexandria,_Virginia "Alexandria, Virginia"); and [TheBus](/wiki/TheBus_(Prince_George%27s_County) "TheBus (Prince George's County)") in [Prince George's County, Maryland](/wiki/Prince_George%27s_County,_Maryland "Prince George's County, Maryland").^[\[346\]](#cite_note-354)^ There are also numerous commuter buses that residents of the wider Washington region take to commute into the city for work or other events. Among these are the [Loudoun County Transit](/wiki/Loudoun_County_Transit "Loudoun County Transit") Commuter Bus and the [Maryland Transit Administration](/wiki/Maryland_Transit_Administration "Maryland Transit Administration") Commuter Bus.^[\[347\]](#cite_note-355)^{#cite_ref-355}

The city also has several bus lines used by tourists and others visiting the city, including [Big Bus Tours](/wiki/Big_Bus_Tours "Big Bus Tours"), Old Town Trolley Tours, and DC Trails. Many tourists also arrive via charter buses.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^  

#### Air {#Air}

See also: [Aviation in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Aviation_in_Washington,_D.C. "Aviation in Washington, D.C."); [List of airports serving Washington, D.C.](/wiki/List_of_airports_serving_Washington,_D.C. "List of airports serving Washington, D.C."); and [List of heliports in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/List_of_heliports_in_Washington,_D.C. "List of heliports in Washington, D.C.")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/NewConcourse-RonaldReaganWashingtonNationalAirport.jpg/220px-NewConcourse-RonaldReaganWashingtonNationalAirport.jpg)](/wiki/File:NewConcourse-RonaldReaganWashingtonNationalAirport.jpg) [Reagan Washington National Airport](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan_Washington_National_Airport "Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport") in [Arlington, Virginia](/wiki/Arlington_County,_Virginia "Arlington County, Virginia") is the closest airport to the city among the three major [Washington metropolitan area](/wiki/Washington_metropolitan_area "Washington metropolitan area") airports.

Three major airports serve the district, though none are within the city's borders. Two of these major airports are located in suburban [Northern Virginia](/wiki/Northern_Virginia "Northern Virginia") and one in suburban [Maryland](/wiki/Maryland "Maryland"). The closest is [Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan_Washington_National_Airport "Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport"), which is located in [Arlington County, Virginia](/wiki/Arlington_County,_Virginia "Arlington County, Virginia"), just across the [Potomac River](/wiki/Potomac_River "Potomac River") about 5 miles (8 km) from downtown Washington, D.C. This airport provides primarily domestic flights and has the lowest number of passengers of the three airports in the region. The busiest by number of total passengers is [Baltimore/Washington International Airport](/wiki/Baltimore/Washington_International_Airport "Baltimore/Washington International Airport") (BWI), located in [Anne Arundel County](/wiki/Anne_Arundel_County,_Maryland "Anne Arundel County, Maryland"), Maryland about 30 miles (48 km) northeast of the city.^[\[348\]](#cite_note-356)^ The busiest by international flights and the largest by land size and amount of facilities is [Washington Dulles International Airport](/wiki/Dulles_International_Airport "Dulles International Airport"), located in [Dulles, Virginia](/wiki/Dulles,_Virginia "Dulles, Virginia"), about 24 miles (39 km) west of the city.^[\[349\]](#cite_note-357)^ Dulles has the most international passenger traffic of any airport in the [Mid-Atlantic](/wiki/Mid-Atlantic_(United_States) "Mid-Atlantic (United States)") outside the [New York metropolitan area](/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area "New York metropolitan area"), including approximately 90% of the international passenger traffic in the [Washington-Baltimore region](/wiki/Washington%E2%80%93Baltimore_metropolitan_area "Washington–Baltimore metropolitan area").^[\[350\]](#cite_note-ACI-358)^ Each of these three airports also serves as a hub for a major American airline: Reagan National Airport is a hub for [American Airlines](/wiki/American_Airlines "American Airlines"),^[\[351\]](#cite_note-359)^ Dulles is a major hub for [United Airlines](/wiki/United_Airlines "United Airlines") and [Star Alliance](/wiki/Star_Alliance "Star Alliance") partners,^[\[352\]](#cite_note-360)^ and BWI is an operating base for [Southwest Airlines](/wiki/Southwest_Airlines "Southwest Airlines").^[\[353\]](#cite_note-361)^ In 2018, the Washington, D.C. area was the [18th-busiest airport system in the world](/wiki/List_of_busiest_city_airport_systems_by_passenger_traffic "List of busiest city airport systems by passenger traffic") by passenger traffic, accumulating over 74 million passengers between its three main commercial airports; by 2022 it had climbed to 13th-busiest for passenger traffic, even though passenger numbers decreased to less than 69 million.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-361}

The [President of the United States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States") does not use any of these airports for travel. Instead, the U.S. president typically travels by [Marine One](/wiki/Marine_One "Marine One") from the [South Lawn](/wiki/South_Lawn "South Lawn") of the [White House](/wiki/White_House "White House") to [Joint Base Andrews](/wiki/Joint_Base_Andrews "Joint Base Andrews") in suburban Maryland. From there, he takes [Air Force One](/wiki/Air_Force_One "Air Force One") to his destination.^[\[354\]](#cite_note-362)^{#cite_ref-362}  

### Utilities {#Utilities}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Blue_Plains_WWTP_-_aerial_2016.jpg/220px-Blue_Plains_WWTP_-_aerial_2016.jpg)](/wiki/File:Blue_Plains_WWTP_-_aerial_2016.jpg) The [Blue Plains Advanced Wastewater Treatment Plant](/wiki/Blue_Plains_Advanced_Wastewater_Treatment_Plant "Blue Plains Advanced Wastewater Treatment Plant") in D.C. is the largest [advanced](/wiki/Sewage_treatment#Tertiary_treatment "Sewage treatment") wastewater treatment facility in the world.^[\[355\]](#cite_note-363)^

The [District of Columbia Water and Sewer Authority](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_Water_and_Sewer_Authority "District of Columbia Water and Sewer Authority"), also known as WASA or D.C. Water, is an independent authority of the Washington, D.C., government that provides drinking water and wastewater collection in the city. WASA purchases water from the historic [Washington Aqueduct](/wiki/Washington_Aqueduct "Washington Aqueduct"), which is operated by the [Army Corps of Engineers](/wiki/United_States_Army_Corps_of_Engineers "United States Army Corps of Engineers"). The water, sourced from the [Potomac River](/wiki/Potomac_River "Potomac River"), is treated and stored in the city's [Dalecarlia](/wiki/Dalecarlia_Reservoir "Dalecarlia Reservoir"), [Georgetown](/wiki/Georgetown_Reservoir "Georgetown Reservoir"), and [McMillan](/wiki/McMillan_Reservoir "McMillan Reservoir") reservoirs. The aqueduct provides drinking water for a total of 1.1 million people in the district and Virginia, including Arlington, Falls Church, and a portion of Fairfax County.^[\[356\]](#cite_note-364)^ The authority also provides [sewage treatment](/wiki/Sewage_treatment "Sewage treatment") services for an additional 1.6 million people in four surrounding Maryland and Virginia counties.^[\[357\]](#cite_note-365)^{#cite_ref-365}

[Pepco](/wiki/Pepco "Pepco") is the city's electric utility and services 793,000 customers in the district and suburban Maryland.^[\[358\]](#cite_note-366)^ An 1889 law prohibits overhead wires within much of the historic City of Washington. As a result, all power lines and telecommunication cables are located underground in downtown Washington, and traffic signals are placed at the edge of the street.^[\[359\]](#cite_note-367)^ A 2013 plan would bury an additional 60 miles (97 km) of primary power lines throughout the district.^[\[360\]](#cite_note-368)^{#cite_ref-368}

[Washington Gas](/wiki/Washington_Gas "Washington Gas") is the city's [natural gas](/wiki/Natural_gas "Natural gas") utility and serves more than a million customers in the district and its suburbs. Incorporated by [Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") in 1848, the company installed the city's first gas lights in the [Capitol](/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol"), [White House](/wiki/White_House "White House"), and along [Pennsylvania Avenue](/wiki/Pennsylvania_Avenue "Pennsylvania Avenue").^[\[361\]](#cite_note-369)^{#cite_ref-369}  

Crime and police {#Crime_and_police}
------------------------------------

Main article: [Crime in Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Crime_in_Washington,_D.C. "Crime in Washington, D.C.")  
See also: [List of law enforcement agencies in the District of Columbia](/wiki/List_of_law_enforcement_agencies_in_the_District_of_Columbia "List of law enforcement agencies in the District of Columbia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/MPDC.MFL.WDC.19January2018_%2839879686101%29.jpg/220px-MPDC.MFL.WDC.19January2018_%2839879686101%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:MPDC.MFL.WDC.19January2018_(39879686101).jpg) [Washington, D.C., police](/wiki/Metropolitan_Police_Department_of_the_District_of_Columbia "Metropolitan Police Department of the District of Columbia") on [Harley-Davidson](/wiki/Harley-Davidson "Harley-Davidson") motorcycles escorting the [March for Life](/wiki/March_for_Life_(Washington,_D.C.) "March for Life (Washington, D.C.)") protest on [Constitution Avenue](/wiki/Constitution_Avenue "Constitution Avenue") in January 2018

Washington has historically endured high crime, particularly violent offences. The city was once described as the "murder capital" of the United States during the early 1990s.^[\[362\]](#cite_note-370)^ The number of murders peaked in 1991 at 479, but then began to decline,^[\[363\]](#cite_note-371)^ reaching a historic low of 88 in 2012, the lowest total since 1961.^[\[364\]](#cite_note-372)^ In 2016, the district's Metropolitan Police Department tallied 135 homicides, a 53% increase from 2012 but a 17% decrease from 2015.^[\[365\]](#cite_note-373)^ By 2019, citywide reports of both property and violent crimes declined from their most recent highs in the mid-1990s.^[\[366\]](#cite_note-374)^^\[*[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")*\]^ However, both 2021 and 2022 saw over 200 homicides each, reflecting an upward trends from prior decades.^[\[367\]](#cite_note-375)^ In 2023, D.C. recorded 274 homicides, a 20-year high and the fifth-highest murder rate among the nation's largest cities.^[\[368\]](#cite_note-376)^{#cite_ref-376}

Many D.C. residents began to press the city government for refusing to prosecute nearly 70% of arrested offenders in 2022. After months of criticism, the rate of unprosecuted cases dropped to 56% by October 2023---albeit still higher than nine of the past 10 years and almost twice what it was in 2013.^[\[369\]](#cite_note-377)^ In February 2024, the [Council of the District of Columbia](/wiki/Council_of_the_District_of_Columbia "Council of the District of Columbia") passed a major bill meant to reduce crime in the city by introducing harsher penalties for arrested offenders.^[\[370\]](#cite_note-378)^ Rising crime and gang activities contributed to some local businesses leaving the city.^[\[371\]](#cite_note-379)^^[\[372\]](#cite_note-380)^{#cite_ref-380}

According to a 2018 report, 67,000 residents, or about 10% of the population, are ex-convicts.^[\[373\]](#cite_note-381)^ An estimated 2,000--2,500 offenders return to the city from prison every year.^[\[374\]](#cite_note-382)^{#cite_ref-382}

On June 26, 2008, the [Supreme Court of the United States](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United States") held in *[District of Columbia v. Heller](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_v._Heller "District of Columbia v. Heller")* that the city's 1976 [handgun ban](/wiki/Firearms_Control_Regulations_Act_of_1975 "Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975") violated the [right to keep and bear arms](/wiki/Right_to_keep_and_bear_arms_in_the_United_States "Right to keep and bear arms in the United States") as protected under the [Second Amendment](/wiki/Second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Second Amendment to the United States Constitution").^[\[375\]](#cite_note-383)^ However, the ruling does not prohibit all forms of gun control; laws requiring firearm registration remain in place, as does the city's assault weapon ban.^[\[376\]](#cite_note-384)^{#cite_ref-384}

In addition to the [Metropolitan Police Department](/wiki/Metropolitan_Police_Department_of_the_District_of_Columbia "Metropolitan Police Department of the District of Columbia"), several [federal law enforcement agencies](/wiki/Federal_law_enforcement_in_the_United_States "Federal law enforcement in the United States") have jurisdiction in the city, including the [U.S. Park Police](/wiki/United_States_Park_Police "United States Park Police"), founded in 1791.^[\[377\]](#cite_note-385)^ Because the [D.C. National Guard](/wiki/D.C._National_Guard "D.C. National Guard") serves a federal district, the president of the United States---and not city officials---has power to deploy it. The president also has the power to take over the police force in emergency situations.^[\[378\]](#cite_note-386)^{#cite_ref-386}  

Sister cities {#Sister_cities}
------------------------------

Washington, D.C., has fifteen official [sister city](/wiki/Sister_city "Sister city") agreements. Each of the listed cities is a national capital except for Sunderland, which includes the town of [Washington](/wiki/Washington,_Tyne_and_Wear "Washington, Tyne and Wear"), the ancestral home of George Washington's family.^[\[379\]](#cite_note-Sunderland-387)^ Paris and Rome are each formally recognized as a partner city due to their special one sister city policy.^[\[380\]](#cite_note-ParisRome-388)^ Listed in the order each agreement was first established, they are:{#cite_ref-ParisRome_388-0}

Explanatory notes {#Explanatory_notes}
--------------------------------------

1. **[\^](#cite_ref-25)** By 1790, the Southern states had largely repaid their overseas debts from the Revolutionary War. The Northern states had not and wanted the federal government to take over their outstanding liabilities. Southern Congressmen agreed to the plan in return for establishing the new national capital at their preferred site on the Potomac River.^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Crew124-24)^{#cite_ref-Crew124_24-1}
{#cite_note-25}
2. **[\^](#cite_ref-27)** The Residence Act allowed the President to select a location within Maryland as far east as the [Anacostia River](/wiki/Anacostia_River "Anacostia River"). However, Washington shifted the federal territory's borders to the southeast and rotated them to include [Alexandria](/wiki/Alexandria,_Virginia "Alexandria, Virginia") at the district's southern tip. In 1791, Congress amended the Residence Act to approve the new site, including territory ceded by Virginia.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-Crew89-26)^{#cite_ref-Crew89_26-1}
{#cite_note-27}
3. **[\^](#cite_ref-128)** Apportionment totals are collected by combining Resident and Overseas population. (For D.C., this is 689545 residents and 1988 overseas population.){#cite_note-128}
{#cite_note-128}
4. **[\^](#cite_ref-130)** Until 1890, the Census Bureau counted the City of Washington, [Georgetown](/wiki/Georgetown_(Washington,_D.C.) "Georgetown (Washington, D.C.)"), and unincorporated portions of [Washington County](/wiki/Washington_County,_D.C. "Washington County, D.C.") as three separate areas. The data provided in this article from before 1890 are calculated as if the District of Columbia were a single municipality as it is today. Population data for each city prior to 1890 are available.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-129)^{#cite_ref-129}
{#cite_note-130}
5. \^ [^***a***^](#cite_ref-fifteen_134-0) [^***b***^](#cite_ref-fifteen_134-1) Estimated using a 15% sub-sample.{#cite_note-fifteen-134}
{#cite_note-fifteen-134}
6. **[\^](#cite_ref-157)** The [territories of the United States](/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States "Territories of the United States") have the highest poverty rates in the United States.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-156)^{#cite_ref-156}
{#cite_note-157}
7. **[\^](#cite_ref-162)** Defined as "members, children who are not members, and others who are not members but are considered participants in the congregation".^[\[155\]](#cite_note-ARDA-161)^{#cite_ref-ARDA_161-0}
{#cite_note-162}
8. **[\^](#cite_ref-316)** The collection includes: 25 million catalogued books, 15.5 million other print items, 4.2 million recordings, 74.5 million manuscripts, 5.6 million maps, and 8.2 million sheet music pieces.^[\[308\]](#cite_note-Year_2020_at_a_Glance-315)^{#cite_ref-Year_2020_at_a_Glance_315-0}
{#cite_note-316}

| The District of Columbia itself, and [Virginia's incorporated cities](/wiki/Independent_city_(Virginia) "Independent city (Virginia)"), are [county equivalents](/wiki/County-equivalent "County-equivalent"). Virginia's incorporated cities are listed under their surrounding county. The incorporated cities bordering more than one county ([Alexandria](/wiki/Alexandria,_Virginia "Alexandria, Virginia"), [Falls Church](/wiki/Falls_Church,_Virginia "Falls Church, Virginia") and [Fredericksburg](/wiki/Fredericksburg,_Virginia "Fredericksburg, Virginia")) are listed under the county they were part of before incorporation as a city. Some [unincorporated areas](/wiki/Unincorporated_areas "Unincorporated areas") and [census-designated places](/wiki/Census-designated_place "Census-designated place") like [Silver Spring](/wiki/Silver_Spring,_Maryland "Silver Spring, Maryland") and [Bethesda](/wiki/Bethesda,_Maryland "Bethesda, Maryland") in Maryland, [Reston](/wiki/Reston,_Virginia "Reston, Virginia") in Virginia, as well as the [County of Arlington](/wiki/Arlington_County,_Virginia "Arlington County, Virginia") in Virginia are also treated as city-like entities (or principal cities) even though they have not been legally incorporated as such.
